The Power of Iterative Filtering for Supervised
Learning with (Heavy) Contamination

Adam R. Klivans klivans@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Konstantinos Stavropoulos kstavrop@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Kevin Tian kjtian@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Arsen Vasilyan arsenvasilyan@gmail.com UT Austin Supported by NSF award AF-1909204 and the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML).Supported by the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML) and by scholarships from Bodossaki Foundation and Leventis Foundation.Supported by the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML).
Abstract

Inspired by recent work on learning with distribution shift, we give a general outlier removal algorithm called iterative polynomial filtering and show a number of striking applications for supervised learning with contamination:

  1. 1.

    We show that any function class that can be approximated by low-degree polynomials with respect to a hypercontractive distribution can be efficiently learned under bounded contamination (also known as nasty noise). This is a surprising resolution to a longstanding gap between the complexity of agnostic learning and learning with contamination, as it was widely believed that low-degree approximators only implied tolerance to label noise.

  2. 2.

    For any function class that admits the (stronger) notion of sandwiching approximators, we obtain near-optimal learning guarantees even with respect to heavy additive contamination, where far more than 1/2121/21 / 2 of the training set may be added adversarially. Prior related work held only for regression and in a list-decodable setting.

  3. 3.

    We obtain the first efficient algorithms for tolerant testable learning of functions of halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave distribution. Even the non-tolerant case for a single halfspace in this setting had remained open.

These results significantly advance our understanding of efficient supervised learning under contamination, a setting that has been much less studied than its unsupervised counterpart.

1 Introduction

Dataset curation is a fundamental part of the training pipeline of modern machine learning models and often appears to be the bottleneck in obtaining models with improved performance [86, 82, 8, 47]. One way to theoretically model this problem is to assume that the learner has access to a—potentially heavily—contaminated dataset and the goal is to learn a model that performs well on some clean underlying target distribution. While there has been tremendous recent progress for unsupervised learning with contamination [56, 21, 75, 76, 6, 39, 55, 15, 84, 5, 20, 9, 58, 90, 31, 26], relatively little is known for supervised learning with contamination, especially for binary classification.

Many efficient algorithms with strong error guarantees have been developed for agnostic learning, a special case of contamination where only the labels are adversarially corrupted [68, 74, 11, 1, 38, 41, 32]. Most of these guarantees, however, had seemed difficult to extend to the more challenging setting of contamination, where both labels and covariates can be adversarially corrupted. In this paper—building on recent work on robust learning and learning with distribution shift [38, 54, 79]—we give a general iterative polynomial filtering procedure that greatly expands the set of known positive results for learning binary classifiers from contaminated datasets (see Tables 1, 2, and 3). In particular, we obtain the surprising conclusion that all known near-optimal error guarantees for agnostic learning (that can be achieved efficiently) can indeed be extended to the setting of contamination.

Learning with Bounded Contamination.

The earliest works that explored learnability beyond label noise date back more than 30 years ago [89, 69]. Since then, the problem has been studied in the context of learning with malicious [89, 69, 72, 85] and nasty [7, 1, 38, 54, 79] noise. Here we focus on the harshest among these noise models, nasty noise, which we call bounded contamination (defined below), in line with recent work in robust learning (see [28, 79]). In this model, the adversary is allowed to replace an arbitrarily chosen but bounded fraction of a clean dataset with arbitrary labeled datapoints.

Definition 1.1 (Bounded Contamination (BC)).

Let 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be some distribution over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, η∈(0,1)𝜂01\eta\in(0,1)italic_η ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and f:𝒳→{±1}:𝑓→𝒳plus-or-minus1f:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_f : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 }. We say that a set of samples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by (𝒟,f)𝒟𝑓(\mathcal{D},f)( caligraphic_D , italic_f ) with bounded contamination of rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η if it is generated as follows for some M≥1𝑀1M\geq 1italic_M ≥ 1.111We use the notation S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG to denote a labeled dataset and distinguish it from its unlabeled counterpart S𝑆Sitalic_S.

  1. 1.

    First, a set S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of M𝑀Mitalic_M i.i.d. examples of the form (𝐱,f⁢(𝐱))𝐱𝑓𝐱(\mathbf{x},f(\mathbf{x}))( bold_x , italic_f ( bold_x ) ), where 𝐱∼𝒟similar-to𝐱𝒟\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D, is drawn.

  2. 2.

    Then, an adversary receives S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, chooses at most η⁢M𝜂𝑀\eta Mitalic_η italic_M labeled examples in S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and substitutes them with an equal number of arbitrary labeled examples S¯advsubscript¯𝑆adv\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to form S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The learner receives a dataset with bounded contamination, and the goal is to output a classifier that enjoys approximately optimal error guarantees on the clean underlying target distribution. It is known that achieving an error better than twice the contamination rate is, in general, impossible [7].

Definition 1.2 (BC-Learning).

An algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is a BC-learner for 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } if on input (ϵ,δ,S¯inp)italic-ϵ𝛿subscript¯𝑆inp(\epsilon,\delta,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), and S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by (𝒟,f)𝒟𝑓(\mathcal{D},f)( caligraphic_D , italic_f ) with bounded contamination η𝜂\etaitalic_η for some distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, some f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C and η∈[0,1)𝜂01\eta\in[0,1)italic_η ∈ [ 0 , 1 ), the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:𝒳→{±1}:ℎ→𝒳plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } such that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over the clean examples in S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

ℙ𝐱∼𝒟[f⁢(𝐱)≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤2⁢η+ϵsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝒟𝑓𝐱ℎ𝐱2𝜂italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[f(\mathbf{x})\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_x ) ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ 2 italic_η + italic_ϵ

The sample complexity of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee. Moreover, a distribution-specific BC-learner with respect to some distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟{\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is a BC-learner that is guaranteed to work only when 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}={\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Most of the computationally efficient algorithms for learning with bounded contamination provide suboptimal error guarantees and apply only to special concept classes [72, 1, 38]. Nevertheless, a recent line of works inspired by advances in learning with distribution shift [49, 78, 54] has given efficient algorithms with near-optimal guarantees for concept classes that admit sandwiching polynomial approximators [54, 79]. In contrast, for agnostic learning (i.e., adversarial label noise), it is well known that the weaker notion of (non-sandwiching) approximating polynomials is sufficient [68], and there is strong evidence of its necessity [42, 37].

Therefore, the following question naturally arises: does the existence of low-degree approximating polynomials imply efficient learnability even with respect to bounded contamination?

In Theorem 4.2, we give a positive answer to this question, thereby resolving a longstanding gap between the complexity of learning with bounded contamination and with adversarial label noise. This is particularly important as it implies exponential improvements for BC-learning of fundamental concept classes like intersections of halfspaces, monotone functions, and convex sets (see Table 2).

Learning with Heavy Contamination.

Perhaps surprisingly, to our knowledge, binary classification beyond bounded contamination is completely unexplored. In contrast, there is a substantial body of work for learning from datasets where only a small proportion comes from the clean distribution in unsupervised settings [21, 39, 84, 9, 58, 90, 26] and linear regression [84, 66, 26]. These works typically provide list-decodable guarantees (i.e., provide multiple candidate hypotheses only one of which has low error) or require access to a small trusted clean sample. Here, we define a new model for learning binary classifiers with heavy additive contamination that outputs a single hypothesis with a strong error guarantee under the clean distribution. Our model is inspired by recent work on regression (a basic supervised learning task) in additive semi-random models [59, 70].

Definition 1.3 (Heavily Contaminated (HC) Datasets).

Let 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG be some distribution over 𝒳×{±1}𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{X}\times\{\pm 1\}caligraphic_X × { ± 1 } (we think of 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG as the clean or uncorrupted distribution). We say that a set of samples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG with Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-heavy contamination if it is generated as follows for some m≤M𝑚𝑀m\leq Mitalic_m ≤ italic_M with M/m≤Q𝑀𝑚𝑄M/m\leq Qitalic_M / italic_m ≤ italic_Q.

  1. 1.

    First, a set S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. labeled examples from 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG is drawn.

  2. 2.

    Then, an adversary receives S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and adds M−m𝑀𝑚M-mitalic_M - italic_m arbitrary labeled examples to form S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The heavy contamination model only allows the adversary to add points, since removing an arbitrary fraction of the clean samples would correspond to learning with truncation [23, 24, 80], which is beyond the scope of this work (see also Remark 4.6). Another difference between Definition 1.1 and Definition 1.3 is that in the HC model, clean labels need not be realized by some function in the given concept class. We instead consider the following quantity

𝗈𝗉𝗍total=minf∈𝒞⁡1|S¯inp|⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯inp𝟙⁡{y≠f⁢(𝐱)},subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝑓𝒞1subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp1𝑦𝑓𝐱\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\frac{1}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm% {inp}}|}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1% }}\{y\neq f(\mathbf{x})\}\,,sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) } , (1.1)

which is the minimum error achievable by the concept class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C on the whole (contaminated) input dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (including the misclassification errors on the clean samples). The error benchmark we consider is a rescaling of 𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, proportional to the heavy contamination ratio Q𝑄Qitalic_Q.

Definition 1.4 (HC-Learning).

An algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is an HC-learner for 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } if on input (ϵ,δ,Q,S¯inp)italic-ϵ𝛿𝑄subscript¯𝑆inp(\epsilon,\delta,Q,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_Q , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), Q≥1𝑄1Q\geq 1italic_Q ≥ 1 and S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-heavily contaminated set of labeled examples generated by distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG (as described in Definition 1.3), the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:𝒳→{±1}:ℎ→𝒳plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } such that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over the clean examples in S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+ϵ, where ⁢𝗈𝗉𝗍total⁢ is given by Eq. ⁢(⁢1.1⁢)subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦ℎ𝐱⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalitalic-ϵ where subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total is given by Eq. italic-(1.1italic-)\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\epsilon\,,\text{ where }% \mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}\text{ is given by Eq. }\eqref{equation:opttotal}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ , where sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by Eq. italic_( italic_)

The (clean) sample complexity of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of clean examples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT needs to contain in order to achieve the above guarantee. Moreover, a distribution-specific HC-learner with respect to 𝒟∗superscript𝒟{\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an HC-learner that is guaranteed to work only when the marginal of 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}={\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We show that the dependence on Ω⁢(Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total)Ω⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total\Omega(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}})roman_Ω ( italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is, in fact, necessary, even if the clean labels are realized by the learned class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C. The quantity Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals the number of errors |S¯inp|⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total⋅subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal classifier on the input set S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divided by the size of the clean dataset. Our lower bound essentially shows the existence of a contamination strategy that forces any HC learner to pay for all the mistakes of the optimal classifier on S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even if these are not made on the clean dataset. This is possible as the learner does not know which subset of S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is clean. In the following, we let 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean:=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]assignsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleansubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}:=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}% }_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] be the optimum error under the clean distribution.

Proposition 1.5 (Informal, see Propositions B.3 and B.2).

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be any non-trivial class. Then, no HC-learner for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C can guarantee error better than 12⋅Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total⋅12𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total\frac{1}{2}\cdot Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when the clean distribution is realizable, i.e., 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean=0subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. Moreover, if |𝒳|<∞𝒳|\mathcal{X}|<\infty| caligraphic_X | < ∞, then no HC-learner for 𝒞all={±1}𝒳subscript𝒞allsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝒳\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{all}}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_all end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can guarantee error better than Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean=0subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Naturally, one might wonder whether the existence of approximating polynomials is sufficient for HC-learning. In Theorem 5.2 we give a negative answer to this question, by providing a lower bound on the sample complexity of HC-learning of monotone functions, which admit low-degree approximators. A recent line of works has used the stronger notion of sandwiching approximators to provide efficient algorithms for various challenging learning tasks [48, 78, 54, 18, 79]. Here, we expand on this paradigm and show that the existence of low-degree sandwiching polynomials implies efficient HC-learning as well (Theorem 4.4).

1.1 Our Results

Learning from Contaminated Datasets.

In Table 1, we present an overview of the upper bounds we obtain as applications of our main theorems on learning with contamination (Theorems 4.2 and 4.4). For comparison, we also provide the corresponding results on learning with label noise from prior work. For the case of bounded contamination, and for constant error and confidence parameters (ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\deltaitalic_ϵ , italic_δ), our results match the best known bounds for learning with label noise, since in both cases, the existence of low-degree polynomial approximators is sufficient. See Tables 2 and 3 for further details.

All of our results work in the distribution-specific setting. Distributional assumptions are unavoidable, as there is strong evidence that distribution-free learning of even the simplest classes (e.g., linear classifiers) in the presence of noise is computationally hard [44, 22]. Although we present our results for specific standard target marginal distributions, our results hold for any hypercontractive (Definition 3.1) marginal 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that can be sampled efficiently, as long as the degree of approximation (resp. sandwiching for HC-learning) of the learned class is low under 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hypercontractive distributions are an extremely wide class of probability distributions, which includes Gaussians, all log-concave distributions over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as well as product distributions over {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. See Appendix C for an overview of relevant results in approximation theory.

On the lower bound side, we show that learning monotone functions with heavy contamination requires exponentially many samples, thereby separating bounded and heavy contamination. For a more thorough discussion on lower bounds for learning with contamination, see Section 5.222We note that although learning with bounded contamination is clearly more challenging than learning with adversarial label noise, many of the known lower bounds for agnostic learning do not transfer directly to BC-learning as formalized in Definition 1.1 for technical reasons. See Section 5 for a way to circumvent this.

Testable Learning.

A recent line of works in learning theory has focused on providing learning algorithms that can verify their distributional assumptions [83, 48, 50, 33, 51, 87, 54]. These algorithms are allowed to either accept and output a classifier with certified optimal performance, or detect a violation of their target distributional assumptions and reject. Here, we provide improved results for a tolerant version of this problem where the algorithm has to accept even if the input distribution is close to the target distribution. Tolerant testable learning was first studied in [54] (see Definition 4.7).

In Theorem 4.8, we show that the existence of low-degree sandwiching polynomials implies efficient tolerant testable learning. Previously, [54] required the existence of low-degree ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-sandwiching polynomials, which is a stronger assumption. Moreover, all of the previous results in testable learning—even the non-tolerant variants—required that the sandwiching polynomials have bounded coefficients. Here, we do not impose such a requirement and obtain the first testable learning results for functions of halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave distribution. All prior work either gave worse error guarantees [51, 50], or required target marginals with strictly sub-exponential tails [48]. See Section 4.3 for more details.

1.2 Our Techniques

Iterative Polynomial Filtering.

All of our results use the same iterative polynomial filtering algorithm of Theorem 3.2 with appropriate hyperparameter choices. The algorithm receives a set Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of data points and filters it, outputting a subset Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that satisfies the following two conditions. First, any low-degree polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p whose absolute expectation 𝔼[|p⁢(𝐱)|]𝔼𝑝𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] over the pre-specified target distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is small, will also have bounded average over Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e. 1|Sfilt|⁢∑𝐱∈Sfiltp⁢(𝐱)1subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filt𝑝𝐱\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}p(\mathbf{x})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) is small. Second, if Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains a set of points S𝑆Sitalic_S that were initially generated independently by 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then only a limited number of points from S𝑆Sitalic_S can be removed by the filtering (the allowed number of removed points is controlled by an appropriate hyperparameter).

Our algorithm is a refined version of bounded-degree outlier removal procedures from robust learning and learning with distribution shift [38, 29, 54, 79]. The general principle behind these algorithms is that one can iteratively find polynomials that violate the desired condition over the input set and use them to filter the input points. In particular, the algorithm removes the points that give such polynomials values larger than a threshold. By choosing this threshold appropriately, one can control the proportion of removed points that lie in the clean set S𝑆Sitalic_S in each step.

Prior work only gave guarantees for squared polynomials [38, 54] and for non-negative polynomials [79]. Here, we give a filtering algorithm that preserves the expectation of any polynomial, as long as its absolute expectation is small with respect to the target distribution. This is crucial for our application in BC-learning. Moreover, our filtering procedure works for any hypercontractive target distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is also true for [38, 54] but not for [79], which only works for the uniform distribution over the hypercube.

Learning with Bounded Contamination.

Our algorithm follows a two-phase approach: (1) Run our outlier-removal algorithm, and obtain a filtered subset Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (2) Following an approach similar to [68], construct a predictor based on the polynomial p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG with smallest ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error on Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We now give a sketch of the analysis of this algorithm and explain how an error of O⁢(η+ϵ)𝑂𝜂italic-ϵO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_η + italic_ϵ ) can be guaranteed. (The optimal dependence of 2⁢η+ϵ2𝜂italic-ϵ2\eta+\epsilon2 italic_η + italic_ϵ is obtained by carefully refining the analysis below.)

What would happen if we ran the phase (2) without filtering the dataset beforehand? As shown in [68], this approach works in the agnostic setting, i.e. when an adversary can corrupt only the labels but not the examples. A key observation in [68] is that if p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximating polynomial for the ground truth f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then after η𝜂\etaitalic_η fraction of data labels are corrupted, the polynomial p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will have an ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error of only at most η+ϵ𝜂italic-ϵ\eta+\epsilonitalic_η + italic_ϵ. However, in the more challenging setting of learning with contamination over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even a single corrupted data-point can cause the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error of p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be arbitrarily large. The reason is that any non-zero polynomial over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be arbitrarily large in absolute value when evaluated at inputs 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x far enough from the origin.

Hence, the first phase of our algorithm aims to filter out such bad input datapoints. The following basic observation is key to our approach: if p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an ϵ4superscriptitalic-ϵ4\epsilon^{4}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximator in ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm for a {±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ ± 1 }-valued function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the average 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[|(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟superscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|(p^{*}(\mathbf{x})% )^{2}-1|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 | ] is at most O⁢(ϵ2)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\epsilon^{2})italic_O ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This observation, together with our filtering guarantee, ensures that the average 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}-1]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ] is likewise bounded by O⁢(ϵ)𝑂italic-ϵO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_ϵ ) while removing almost exclusively outliers.

Yet, the set Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT might still contain many outliers. We show that the condition 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1]≤O⁢(ϵ)subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21𝑂italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}-1]\leq O(\epsilon)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ] ≤ italic_O ( italic_ϵ ) implies that the remaining outliers are not dangerous when it comes to phase (2) of our algorithm. Indeed, this condition tells us that the number of remaining outliers 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x in Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with |p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τsuperscript𝑝𝐱𝜏|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ is at most O⁢(|Sfilt|⁢ϵ/τ2)𝑂subscript𝑆filtitalic-ϵsuperscript𝜏2O({|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\epsilon}/{\tau^{2}})italic_O ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_ϵ / italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Taking τ=2𝜏2\tau=2italic_τ = 2, we see that the total contribution to the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of outliers 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x with |p∗⁢(𝐱)|>2superscript𝑝𝐱2|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>2| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > 2 is O⁢(ϵ)𝑂italic-ϵO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_ϵ ). The remaining outliers contribute at most O⁢(η)𝑂𝜂O(\eta)italic_O ( italic_η ) to this error, since there are at most O⁢(η)𝑂𝜂O(\eta)italic_O ( italic_η ) of such outliers and each satisfies |p∗⁢(𝐱)|≤2superscript𝑝𝐱2|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\leq 2| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ≤ 2.

Overall, we see that the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most O⁢(η+ϵ)𝑂𝜂italic-ϵO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_η + italic_ϵ ), and therefore the polynomial p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG found in phase 2 of our algorithm will also have an ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of at most O⁢(η+ϵ)𝑂𝜂italic-ϵO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_η + italic_ϵ ) on Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since phase (1) only removed at most O⁢(ϵ)𝑂italic-ϵO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_ϵ ) clean datapoints, we conclude that the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG on the clean dataset Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is likewise O⁢(η+ϵ)𝑂𝜂italic-ϵO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_η + italic_ϵ ), which we use to bound the out-of-distribution error of p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG.

Learning with Heavy Contamination.

Our heavy contamination algorithm follows the same structure as the one for bounded contamination: we first run the iterative filtering algorithm and then run ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression on the filtered dataset. This time, however, we choose the hyperparameters of the iterative filtering algorithm so that the proportion of removed points that are clean is inversely proportional to the heavy contamination ratio Q𝑄Qitalic_Q. In this way, we make sure to remove only a small fraction of the clean points.

To conclude the proof, we use the notion of sandwiching polynomials. In particular, if f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C is the optimum classifier on the input dataset, and pup,pdownsubscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two low-degree polynomials such that (1) pup⁢(𝐱)≥f∗⁢(𝐱)≥pdown⁢(𝐱)subscript𝑝up𝐱superscript𝑓𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})\geq f^{*}(\mathbf{x})\geq p_{\mathrm{down}}(% \mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ≥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ≥ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) for all 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x and (2) 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]≤O⁢(ϵ2/Q)subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟subscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑄\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq O(\epsilon^{2}/Q)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ italic_O ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Q ), then the filtering process guarantees that 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] scales proportionally to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ. Overall, this implies that pdownsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has low ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error under Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-polynomial regression achieves near-optimal error guarantees.

1.3 Related Work

Supervised Learning with Noise.

The majority of existing works on robust supervised learning focus on label noise. In order to obtain efficient algorithms, it is standard and often necessary to make assumptions on the marginal distribution [22, 27, 35], although there have been recent attempts to relax those assumptions [17]. Even under common distributional assumptions, the best possible error guarantees often require exponential dependence on the excess error parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ [42, 37]. A line of works was focused on providing faster learning algorithms for some classes at the expense of relaxed error guarantees [1, 38, 41] or under restricted noise models [40, 32]. We consider the more challenging scenario of learning with contamination, where there is noise on both the input examples and their labels. Before this work, efficient algorithms for learning with bounded contamination up to optimal error were known only for classes with low sandwiching degree [54, 79], and nothing was known about classification under heavy contamination.

Semi-Random Models.

Our Definition 1.3 is inspired by semi-random models, which lie between the average and worst case settings [13, 45]. In particular, it resembles an instantiation of the semi-random model framework known as a monotone adversary, which breaks a statistical assumption used by a learning algorithm (e.g., i.i.d. draws from a known distribution) by providing additional data. Our approach is inspired by recent algorithms for supervised regression problems, e.g., solving linear systems, sparse recovery, or matrix completion [16, 70, 59, 71], that are tolerant to monotone adversaries. These algorithms also use reweightings that come with certificates of success. However, a major qualitative difference between the aforementioned works and ours is that our Definition 1.3 does not require that the adversary uses labels consistent with a “clean hypothesis.” Instead, our algorithms can tolerate label noise (alongside covariate noise) and achieve the information-theoretically optimal clean error under such a model (Proposition 1.5).

Testable Learning.

In recent years, a number of works has focused on verifying the assumptions of learning algorithms. Testable learning was introduced by [83] in the context of verifying the distributional assumptions of agnostic learners and there are several subsequent works on this setting [48, 51, 33, 50, 34, 87]. This paradigm has since been expanded to testing for distribution shifts that may harm the performance of supervised learning algorithms [78, 77, 18, 19], or even testing noise assumptions [52]. Here, we study a tolerant version of testable agnostic learning that was first studied by [54], and provide the first guarantees for halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave measure.

Learning with heavy contamination can be thought of as a search version of testable learning. More specifically, in testable learning the goal is to decide whether the input dataset is structured enough so that a near-optimal hypothesis can be found efficiently, while in HC-learning the goal is to find a subset of the input that is structured enough. An analogous connection was observed in [54] between TDS learning [78] and PQ learning [49] in the context of learning under distribution shift. There, the goal was to either decide whether the (unlabeled) test examples come from a distribution that is similar to the one the learner has trained on (TDS), or find a subset of the test examples where the learner is confident in its predictions (PQ). See Remark 4.5.

2 Notation

We consider a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional feature space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X which will either be ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or the hypercube {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is of the form p⁢(𝐱)=∑α⊆ℕdcp⁢(α)⁢𝐱α𝑝𝐱subscript𝛼superscriptℕ𝑑subscript𝑐𝑝𝛼superscript𝐱𝛼p(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{\alpha\subseteq{\mathbb{N}}^{d}}c_{p}(\alpha)\,\mathbf{x}^% {\alpha}italic_p ( bold_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α ⊆ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α ) bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where 𝐱α=∏i∈[d]xiαisuperscript𝐱𝛼subscriptproduct𝑖delimited-[]𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\mathbf{x}^{\alpha}=\prod_{i\in[d]}x_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a monomial of degree ‖α‖1subscriptnorm𝛼1\|\alpha\|_{1}∥ italic_α ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The degree of p𝑝pitalic_p is equal to the maximum ‖α‖1subscriptnorm𝛼1\|\alpha\|_{1}∥ italic_α ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that cp⁢(α)≠0subscript𝑐𝑝𝛼0c_{p}(\alpha)\neq 0italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α ) ≠ 0. Over {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we use the multilinear expansion p⁢(𝐱)=∑ℐ⊆[d]cp⁢(ℐ)⁢𝐱ℐ𝑝𝐱subscriptℐdelimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑐𝑝ℐsuperscript𝐱ℐp(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{\mathcal{I}\subseteq[d]}c_{p}(\mathcal{I})\mathbf{x}^{% \mathcal{I}}italic_p ( bold_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ⊆ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_I ) bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where 𝐱ℐ=∏i∈ℐxisuperscript𝐱ℐsubscriptproduct𝑖ℐsubscript𝑥𝑖\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{I}}=\prod_{i\in\mathcal{I}}x_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ caligraphic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In both cases, we call 𝐜psubscript𝐜𝑝\mathbf{c}_{p}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the vector of coefficients. We consider sets of points S𝑆Sitalic_S to contain examples that are separate instances of the correponding elements of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. We denote with S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG the corresponding labeled set of examples. We use 𝐱∼Ssimilar-to𝐱𝑆\mathbf{x}\sim Sbold_x ∼ italic_S to say that 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x is drawn uniformly from S𝑆Sitalic_S. For a labeled distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG over 𝒳×{±1}𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{X}\times\{\pm 1\}caligraphic_X × { ± 1 }, 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is the marginal on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. In the following the distribution-specific algorithms have sample access to the unlabeled target distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We use 𝒩d=𝒩⁢(0,𝐈d)subscript𝒩𝑑𝒩0subscript𝐈𝑑\mathcal{N}_{d}=\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{d})caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_N ( 0 , bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to denote the standard d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional Gaussian and Unifd=Unif⁢{±1}dsubscriptUnif𝑑Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\mathrm{Unif}_{d}=\mathrm{Unif}\{\pm 1\}^{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Unif { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the uniform over the d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional hypercube.

3 Iterative Polynomial Filtering

We first define hypercontractivity, which is a crucial assumption for our filtering procedure.

Definition 3.1 (Hypercontractivity).

We say that a distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is A𝐴{A}italic_A-hypercontractive with respect to polynomials for some A≥1𝐴1{A}\geq 1italic_A ≥ 1 if for any polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X and any t≥2𝑡2t\geq 2italic_t ≥ 2 we have

  1. 1.

    𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p(𝐱)|t]≤(At)ℓ⁢t(𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p(𝐱)|])t, where ℓ=deg(p)\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|^{t}]% \leq({A}t)^{\ell t}\bigr{(}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{% D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\bigr{)}^{t}\,,\text{ where }\ell=\deg(p)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ ( italic_A italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , where roman_ℓ = roman_deg ( italic_p )

  2. 2.

    The absolute value of any degree-1111 monomial has finite expectation under 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D.

Our main algorithmic tool is the following theorem, which gives a way to filter an arbitrary set of examples in order to preserve the expectations of polynomials whose expected absolute value under some hypercontractive target distribution is small.

Theorem 3.2 (Iterative Filtering).

Let 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a A𝐴{A}italic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. Consider parameters ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and R,ℓ,m≥1𝑅ℓ𝑚1R,\ell,m\geq 1italic_R , roman_ℓ , italic_m ≥ 1, and let Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an arbitrary set of examples in 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X and Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a set of mrefsubscript𝑚refm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT i.i.d. examples from 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a sufficiently large universal constant C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1italic_C ≥ 1, if mref≥R2⁢(C⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓϵ3⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscript𝑅2superscript𝐶𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ3superscript1𝛿4ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq\frac{R^{2}(CAd)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{3}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then Algorithm 1 on input (Sinp,Sref,m,ℓ,R,ϵ)subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆ref𝑚ℓ𝑅italic-ϵ(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m,\ell,R,\epsilon)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m , roman_ℓ , italic_R , italic_ϵ ) runs in time poly⁡(|Sinp|,mref,(d+1)ℓ)polysubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑚refsuperscript𝑑1ℓ\operatorname{poly}(|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,m_{\mathrm{ref}},(d+1)^{\ell})roman_poly ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and outputs Sfilt⊆Sinpsubscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{filt}}\subseteq S_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the following hold:

  1. 1.

    Let Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be any set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. examples from 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where m≥C⁢R2⁢(2⁢A⁢(d+1))2⁢ℓϵ3⁢log⁡1δ𝑚𝐶superscript𝑅2superscript2𝐴𝑑12ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ31𝛿m\geq CR^{2}\frac{(2A(d+1))^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{3}}\log\frac{1}{\delta}italic_m ≥ italic_C italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( 2 italic_A ( italic_d + 1 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG. Suppose that Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is formed by first removing an arbitrary fraction of points in Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then adding any number of arbitrary points. Then, the algorithm removes a relatively small number of the examples in Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that appear in Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

    |(Scln∩Sinp)∖Sfilt|≤1R⋅|Sinp∖Sfilt|+ϵ⁢m2, with probability at least ⁢1−δ⁢ over ⁢Scln,Srefsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filt⋅1𝑅subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚2 with probability at least 1𝛿 over subscript𝑆clnsubscript𝑆ref|(S_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap S_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq\frac{% 1}{R}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{2}\,% ,\text{ with probability at least }1-\delta\text{ over }S_{\mathrm{cln}},S_{% \mathrm{ref}}| ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ⋅ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , with probability at least 1 - italic_δ over italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
  2. 2.

    For any polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, and 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ4⁢Rsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ4𝑅\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]% \leq\frac{\epsilon}{4R}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_R end_ARG we have:

    ∑𝐱∈Sfiltp⁢(𝐱)≤ϵ⁢m, with probability at least ⁢1−δ⁢ over ⁢Srefsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filt𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚 with probability at least 1𝛿 over subscript𝑆ref\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}p(\mathbf{x})\leq\epsilon m\,,\text{ % with probability at least }1-\delta\text{ over }S_{\mathrm{ref}}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) ≤ italic_ϵ italic_m , with probability at least 1 - italic_δ over italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

The algorithm iteratively removes the points that give large values to polynomials that do not satisfy the stopping criterion of line 1. The hyperparameter R𝑅Ritalic_R determines how selective the filtering is: larger values of R𝑅Ritalic_R imply that less points will be removed in each iteration, and the proportion of removed points that are clean is smaller. The price one has to pay for larger choices of R𝑅Ritalic_R is that the guarantee of part 2 holds for polynomials with smaller absolute expectation under the target distribution.

Our algorithm requires access to a set of reference samples from the target distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and uses them to restrict its attention to polynomials with the desired properties under 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The stopping criterion ensures that upon completion all of these polynomials will have bounded expectations under the empirical distribution over the filtered set. The bound depends on the hyperparameters ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ (target error) and m𝑚mitalic_m (effective size), but not on the degree ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ of the polynomials considered.

We now give the proof of our main technical tool, Theorem 3.2. The proof follows the approach of [79], but has a number of technical differences. In particular, the algorithm of [79] only gives guarantees for non-negative polynomials and works with respect to the uniform distribution on the hypercube. Here, we preserve the expectation of any polynomial, with respect to any target hypercontractive distribution that can be sampled efficiently.

Proof of Theorem 3.2.

We first observe that the family 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P of polynomials p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ for which 𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤γsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆ref𝑝𝐱𝛾\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\gammablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_γ and 𝔼𝐱∼Sref[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤βsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱2𝛽\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\leq\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_β can be described by O⁢(mref)𝑂subscript𝑚refO(m_{\mathrm{ref}})italic_O ( italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) linear constraints plus one convex quadratic constraint over the coefficient vectors whose dimension is (d+1)ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, lines 1 and 5 can be implemented as convex programs in time poly⁡(|Sinp|,mref,(d+1)ℓ)polysubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑚refsuperscript𝑑1ℓ\operatorname{poly}(|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,m_{\mathrm{ref}},(d+1)^{\ell})roman_poly ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Lines 1 and 1 can be implemented with a single pass of the input points.

We first prove the following claim, which ensures that lines 1 and 1 are well defined.

Claim.

When λ∗>ϵsuperscript𝜆italic-ϵ\lambda^{*}>\epsilonitalic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_ϵ, there exists τ∗≥0superscript𝜏0\tau^{*}\geq 0italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0 that satisfies the guarantees of line 1.

Proof.

Suppose, for contradiction, that for any τ≥0𝜏0\tau\geq 0italic_τ ≥ 0 we have

|S|m⁢ℙ𝐱∼S[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]<R⋅ℙ𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]+Δ𝑆𝑚subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱𝜏⋅𝑅subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱𝜏Δ\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|% >\tau]<R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{% *}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]+\Deltadivide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] < italic_R ⋅ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] + roman_Δ

We may now integrate both sides of the inequality over τ∈[0,B]𝜏0𝐵\tau\in[0,B]italic_τ ∈ [ 0 , italic_B ], since it holds for all τ≥0𝜏0\tau\geq 0italic_τ ≥ 0. Note that |p∗⁢(𝐱)|≥0superscript𝑝𝐱0|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\geq 0| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ≥ 0 for all 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x and, therefore, the following are true

𝔼𝐱∼S[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] =∫τ=0∞ℙ𝐱∼S[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]⁢𝑑τ=∫τ=0Bℙ𝐱∼S[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]⁢𝑑τabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱𝜏differential-d𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱𝜏differential-d𝜏\displaystyle=\int_{\tau=0}^{\infty}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S% }[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau=\int_{\tau=0}^{B}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] italic_d italic_τ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] italic_d italic_τ (3.1)
𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{% *}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] =∫τ=0∞ℙ𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]⁢𝑑τ≥∫τ=0Bℙ𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ]⁢𝑑τabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱𝜏differential-d𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱𝜏differential-d𝜏\displaystyle=\int_{\tau=0}^{\infty}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S% _{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau\geq\int_{\tau=0}^{B}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|>\tau]\;d\tau= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] italic_d italic_τ ≥ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] italic_d italic_τ (3.2)

The second equality in Eq. (3.1) follows from the fact that for any p∗∈𝒫superscript𝑝𝒫p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P, S𝑆Sitalic_S contains only points such that p∗⁢(𝐱)∈[−B,B]superscript𝑝𝐱𝐵𝐵p^{*}(\mathbf{x})\in[-B,B]italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ∈ [ - italic_B , italic_B ], due to line 1. The inequality in Eq. (3.2) follows from the fact that the integrated function is non-negative. Overall, we obtain the following inequality

λ∗=|S|m⁢𝔼𝐱∼S[p∗⁢(𝐱)]≤|S|m⁢𝔼𝐱∼S[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]<R⋅𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]+Δ⁢B≤ϵ,superscript𝜆𝑆𝑚subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱𝑆𝑚subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱⋅𝑅subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱Δ𝐵italic-ϵ\lambda^{*}=\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[p^{*}(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^% {*}(\mathbf{x})|]<R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{% ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]+\Delta B\leq\epsilon\,,italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] < italic_R ⋅ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] + roman_Δ italic_B ≤ italic_ϵ ,

where the last inequality follows from the fact that p∗∈𝒫superscript𝑝𝒫p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P and, hence, 𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ2⁢Rsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ2𝑅\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|]\leq\frac{\epsilon}{2R}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_R end_ARG and Δ=ϵ2⁢BΔitalic-ϵ2𝐵\Delta=\frac{\epsilon}{2B}roman_Δ = divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_B end_ARG. We have reached contradiction, because we showed that λ∗≤ϵsuperscript𝜆italic-ϵ\lambda^{*}\leq\epsilonitalic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ. ∎

Note that due to the claim above, we have {𝐱∈S:|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ∗}≠∅conditional-set𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱superscript𝜏\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}\neq\emptyset{ bold_x ∈ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ≠ ∅. This means that at each iteration we remove at least one point from the input dataset and, therefore, we do not need more than M=|Sinp|𝑀subscript𝑆inpM=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|italic_M = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | iterations. The following claim ensures that we only remove a small fraction of clean points from Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Claim.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have

|(Scln∩Sinp)∖Sfilt|≤ϵ⁢m2+1R⋅|Sinp∖Sfilt|subscript𝑆clnsubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚2⋅1𝑅subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filt|(S_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap S_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq\frac{% \epsilon m}{2}+\frac{1}{R}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|| ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ⋅ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |
Proof.

We will show that with high probability over the clean and reference datasets, the number of removed points from Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small. First, we account for the initial filtering of line 1. In this step, we remove points 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x from Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that give large absolute values to polynomials in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, i.e., polynomials who, in particular, have bounded second norms over Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Due to Lemma A.2 and since mref≥(C⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscript𝐶𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscript1𝛿4ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq(CAd)^{2\ell}(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the probability that some 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x drawn from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D gives |p⁢(𝐱)|>B𝑝𝐱𝐵|p(\mathbf{x})|>B| italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_B for some p∈𝒫𝑝𝒫p\in\mathcal{P}italic_p ∈ caligraphic_P is at most ϵ/4italic-ϵ4\epsilon/4italic_ϵ / 4. Therefore, the total number of points removed from Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in this step follows the binomial distribution with m𝑚mitalic_m number of trials and probability of success at most ϵ/4italic-ϵ4\epsilon/4italic_ϵ / 4. By a standard Chernoff bound, and since m≥Cϵ⁢log⁡(1/δ)𝑚𝐶italic-ϵ1𝛿m\geq\frac{C}{\epsilon}\log(1/\delta)italic_m ≥ divide start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ), with probability at least 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/21 - italic_δ / 2 we have

|{𝐱∈Scln:|p⁢(𝐱)|>B⁢ for some ⁢p∈𝒫}|≤ϵ⁢m/2conditional-set𝐱subscript𝑆cln𝑝𝐱𝐵 for some 𝑝𝒫italic-ϵ𝑚2|\{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{cln}}:|p(\mathbf{x})|>B\text{ for some }p\in% \mathcal{P}\}|\leq\epsilon m/2| { bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_B for some italic_p ∈ caligraphic_P } | ≤ italic_ϵ italic_m / 2 (3.3)

It remains to account for the points removed in line 1. The removed points are always of the form {𝐱∈S:|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ∗}conditional-set𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱superscript𝜏\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}{ bold_x ∈ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } for some p∗∈𝒫superscript𝑝𝒫p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P. Moreover, according to line 1, we have

1m⁢∑𝐱∈S𝟙⁡{|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ∗}≥R⋅ℙ𝐱∼Sref[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|>τ∗]+Δ1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑆1superscript𝑝𝐱superscript𝜏⋅𝑅subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱superscript𝜏Δ\frac{1}{m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|>\tau^{*}\}\geq R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{% ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}]+\Deltadivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ≥ italic_R ⋅ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + roman_Δ

Since m,mref≥C′⁢(d+1)ℓ+log⁡(1/δ)(Δ/R)2𝑚subscript𝑚refsuperscript𝐶′superscript𝑑1ℓ1𝛿superscriptΔ𝑅2m,m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq C^{\prime}\frac{(d+1)^{\ell}+\log(1/\delta)}{(\Delta/R)% ^{2}}italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_Δ / italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG for some sufficiently large universal constant C′≥1superscript𝐶′1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 1 and the VC dimension of the class of polynomial threshold functions of degree ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is at most (d+1)ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that with probability at least 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/21 - italic_δ / 2 over Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the following holds for all polynomials p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and all τ≥0𝜏0\tau\geq 0italic_τ ≥ 0

R⋅ℙ𝐱∼Scln[|p⁢(𝐱)|>τ]≤R⋅ℙ𝐱∼Sref[|p⁢(𝐱)|>τ]+Δ,⋅𝑅subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆cln𝑝𝐱𝜏⋅𝑅subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑆ref𝑝𝐱𝜏ΔR\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|p(\mathbf{% x})|>\tau]\leq R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref% }}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]+\Delta\,,italic_R ⋅ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] ≤ italic_R ⋅ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ ] + roman_Δ ,

since Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both i.i.d. samples from the distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝟙⁡{|p⁢(𝐱)|>τ}1𝑝𝐱𝜏\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{|p(\mathbf{x})|>\tau\}blackboard_1 { | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ } is equal to the sum of two degree-ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ polynomial threshold functions, 𝟙⁡{p⁢(𝐱)>τ}+𝟙⁡{p⁢(𝐱)<−τ}1𝑝𝐱𝜏1𝑝𝐱𝜏\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{p(\mathbf{x})>\tau\}+\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{p% (\mathbf{x})<-\tau\}blackboard_1 { italic_p ( bold_x ) > italic_τ } + blackboard_1 { italic_p ( bold_x ) < - italic_τ }. Therefore:

|{𝐱∈S:|p∗(𝐱)|>τ∗}|≥R⋅|{𝐱∈Scln:|p∗(𝐱)|>τ∗|,|\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}|\geq R\cdot|\{\mathbf{x}\in S% _{\mathrm{cln}}:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}|\,,| { bold_x ∈ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } | ≥ italic_R ⋅ | { bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ,

for any update we make. Summing over all the updates, we obtain that the total number of points removed from Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the updates of line 1 is at most

(1/R)⋅|Sinp∖Sfilt|⋅1𝑅subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filt(1/R)\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|( 1 / italic_R ) ⋅ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (3.4)

By combining Eq. (3.3) and (3.4), we obtain the desired result, where the probability of failure is at most δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ due to a union bound. ∎

So far, we have proven the first part of Theorem 3.2. We will now prove the second part, by showing the following claim.

Claim.

Any polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ/(4⁢R)subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ4𝑅\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \epsilon/(4R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_ϵ / ( 4 italic_R ), lies within 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Fix any polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p with 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ/(4⁢R)subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ4𝑅\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \epsilon/(4R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_ϵ / ( 4 italic_R ). Due to the hypercontractivity of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D (Definition 3.1), we have 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤(2⁢A)2⁢ℓ=β/2subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑝𝐱2superscript2𝐴2ℓ𝛽2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq(2A)^{2\ell}=\beta/2blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ ( 2 italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_β / 2, since 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤1subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱1\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq 1blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ 1. By Lemma A.1, since mrefsubscript𝑚refm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is large enough, w.p. at least 1−δ21𝛿21-\frac{\delta}{2}1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG over Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have 𝔼𝐱∼Sref[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤βsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆refsuperscript𝑝𝐱2𝛽\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\leq\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_β.

It remains to show that with probability at least 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/21 - italic_δ / 2, we have 𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤γ=ϵ/(2⁢R)subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆ref𝑝𝐱𝛾italic-ϵ2𝑅\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]% \leq\gamma=\epsilon/(2R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_γ = italic_ϵ / ( 2 italic_R ). The following bound can be obtained for any t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1italic_t ≥ 1 by applying the Marcinkiewicz–Zygmund inequality (see [43]), due to the fact that Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists of mrefsubscript𝑚refm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT i.i.d. examples.

ℙSref∼𝒟mref[|𝔼𝐱∼Sref[|p(𝐱)|]−𝔼𝐱′∼𝒟[|p(𝐱′)|]|>ϵ4⁢R]≤2(32⁢R2⁢tϵ2⁢mref)t𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[||p(𝐱)|−𝔼𝐱′∼𝒟[|p(𝐱′)|]|2⁢t]\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{S_{\mathrm{ref}}\sim\mathcal{D}^{m_{\mathrm{ref}}}% }\Bigr{[}\Bigr{|}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[% |p(\mathbf{x})|]-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D% }}[|p(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})|]\Bigr{|}>\frac{\epsilon}{4R}\Bigr{]}\leq 2\Bigr{(}% \frac{32R^{2}t}{\epsilon^{2}m_{\mathrm{ref}}}\Bigr{)}^{t}\operatorname*{% \mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}\Bigr{[}\Bigr{|}|p(\mathbf{x})|-% \operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x}^% {\prime})|]\Bigr{|}^{2t}\Bigr{]}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | ] | > divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_R end_ARG ] ≤ 2 ( divide start_ARG 32 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | | italic_p ( bold_x ) | - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | ] | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]

To conclude the proof of the claim, we use the simple inequality (a+b)2⁢t≤4t⁢max⁡{a2⁢t,b2⁢t}superscript𝑎𝑏2𝑡superscript4𝑡superscript𝑎2𝑡superscript𝑏2𝑡(a+b)^{2t}\leq 4^{t}\max\{a^{2t},b^{2t}\}( italic_a + italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ 4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max { italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } for all a,b,t≥0𝑎𝑏𝑡0a,b,t\geq 0italic_a , italic_b , italic_t ≥ 0 as well as hypercontractivity to bound the expectation on the right-hand side by (8At)2⁢ℓ⁢t𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p(𝐱)|]2⁢t(8At)^{2\ell t}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(% \mathbf{x})|]^{2t}( 8 italic_A italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Due to the choice of mrefsubscript𝑚refm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if we choose t=log⁡(1/δ)𝑡1𝛿t=\log(1/\delta)italic_t = roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ), we obtain a bound of δ/2𝛿2\delta/2italic_δ / 2, as desired. ∎

This concludes the proof of Theorem 3.2. ∎

4 Applications

4.1 Learning with Bounded Contamination

We give results for BC-learning of any concept class that can be approximated by low-degree polynomials in ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance.

Definition 4.1 (Polynomial Approximators).
