For ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_ϵ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } has ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree ℓ=ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓℓitalic-ϵ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ = roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) with respect to some distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C there is a polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) such that 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[(f⁢(𝐱)−p⁢(𝐱))2]≤ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟superscript𝑓𝐱𝑝𝐱2italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[(f(\mathbf{x})-p(% \mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_ϵ.

Our main result additionally requires that the target marginal distribution is hypercontractive. This assumption is inherited by Theorem 3.2.

Theorem 4.2 (Polynomial Approximation implies BC-Learning).

Let ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and A≥1𝐴1A\geq 1italic_A ≥ 1. Let 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some A𝐴Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional space and let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose ϵ4Csuperscriptitalic-ϵ4𝐶\frac{\epsilon^{4}}{{C}}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG-approximate degree w.r.t. 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ for some large enough universal constant C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1italic_C ≥ 1. Then, there is an algorithm that (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-learns 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C under bounded contamination with respect to 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in time poly⁡(Aℓ,(log⁡1δ)ℓ,(d+1)ℓ,1ϵ)polysuperscript𝐴ℓsuperscript1𝛿ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ1italic-ϵ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},\frac{% 1}{\epsilon})roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ), and has (clean) sample complexity at most 1ϵ6⁢O⁢(A⁢d⁢log⁡(1/δ))4⁢ℓ+11superscriptitalic-ϵ6𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑1𝛿4ℓ1\frac{1}{\epsilon^{6}}O(Ad\log(1/\delta))^{4\ell+1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_O ( italic_A italic_d roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

In Table 2, we summarize some of the new results we obtain as corollaries of Theorem 4.2, combined with appropriate known bounds on the approximate degree (see Section C.1). We also present the previous state-of-the-art results for comparison. For monotone functions and convex sets, no non-trivial results were known before this work. For halfspace intersections, we obtain exponential improvements over prior work, and for polynomial threshold functions, we obtain the first near-optimal error bounds. For small-depth circuits, we obtain an improved dependence on the depth.

Our results nearly match the best known upper bounds for agnostic learning, albeit with a worse dependence on the excess error parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ. In particular, to achieve excess error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ, we require O⁢(ϵ4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O(\epsilon^{4})italic_O ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximating polynomials, while for agnostic learning an O⁢(ϵ2)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\epsilon^{2})italic_O ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximation suffices. Therefore, our results imply, for example, a runtime of dO~(log(k)/ϵ8d^{\tilde{O}(\log(k)/\epsilon^{8}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for BC-learning of k𝑘kitalic_k-halfspace intersections with respect to 𝒩dsubscript𝒩𝑑\mathcal{N}_{d}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but agnostic learning can be done in dO~(log(k)/ϵ4d^{\tilde{O}(\log(k)/\epsilon^{4}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [74].

The proof of Theorem 4.2 is based on a delicate analysis of the error on the filtered dataset obtained by applying Theorem 3.2. The filtering algorithm is used to preserve the following important property of any polynomial p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that approximates a boolean function:

𝔼[(p∗⁢(𝐱))2]≤1+O⁢(ϵ)𝔼superscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21𝑂italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 1+O(\epsilon)blackboard_E [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 1 + italic_O ( italic_ϵ ) (4.1)

We show that obtaining a filtered set that preserves this property is sufficient for learning with bounded contamination. To prove this, we crucially use the fact that the noise is bounded and that the right hand side of Eq. (4.1) is approximately equal to 1111 (rather than some larger constant). On the other hand, by applying part 2 of Theorem 3.2 on the polynomial q⁢(𝐱)=(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1𝑞𝐱superscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21q(\mathbf{x})=(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}-1italic_q ( bold_x ) = ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1, we are able to ensure the desired property for p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the filtered set. We give the full proof of our main result on learning with bounded contamination (Theorem 4.2) below.

Proof of Theorem 4.2.

The algorithm receives a dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by (𝒟∗,f∗)superscript𝒟superscript𝑓(\mathcal{D}^{*},f^{*})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with bounded contamination of rate η∈(0,1)𝜂01\eta\in(0,1)italic_η ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), where f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C and η,f∗𝜂superscript𝑓\eta,f^{*}italic_η , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are unknown, draws a set Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=(C′⁢A⁢d)4⁢ℓϵ6⁢(log⁡1δ)8⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴𝑑4ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ6superscript1𝛿8ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{(C^{\prime}Ad)^{4\ell}}{\epsilon^{6}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{8\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where C′≥1superscript𝐶′1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of Theorem 3.2 (that is, Algorithm 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=|Sinp|,2⁢ℓ,R=2,24⁢ϵ2/C)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆ref𝑚subscript𝑆inp2ℓ𝑅224superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐶(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,2\ell,R=2,24\epsilon^{% 2}/{\sqrt{C}})( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , 2 roman_ℓ , italic_R = 2 , 24 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ) to form the filtered dataset S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the labels are consistent with S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ that minimizes the following convex objective.

    p^=arg⁡minp^𝑝subscript𝑝\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 𝔼(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[|y−p⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]
    s.t. p⁢ has degree at most ⁢ℓ𝑝 has degree at most ℓ\displaystyle p\text{ has degree at most }\ellitalic_p has degree at most roman_ℓ
  3. 3.

    The algorithm outputs h⁢(𝐱)=sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ^)ℎ𝐱sign^𝑝𝐱^𝜏h(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ), where τ^∈ℝ^𝜏ℝ\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦sign^𝑝𝐱𝜏\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_τ ) ] over τ∈ℝ𝜏ℝ\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_τ ∈ blackboard_R.

We will now bound the error of hℎhitalic_h on the clean dataset S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to which S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was formed (see Definition 1.1). This suffices because, due to standard VC theory, and since hℎhitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, as long as m=|S¯cln|≥C′⁢(d+1)ℓ+log⁡1δϵ2𝑚subscript¯𝑆clnsuperscript𝐶′superscript𝑑1ℓ1𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ2m=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|\geq C^{\prime}\frac{(d+1)^{\ell}+\log\frac{1}{% \delta}}{\epsilon^{2}}italic_m = | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG for some sufficiently large universal constant C′≥1superscript𝐶′1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 1, we have that ℙ𝐱∼𝒟[f∗⁢(𝐱)≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑓𝐱ℎ𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[f^{*}(\mathbf{x})\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] is approximately equal to its empirical counterpart ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦ℎ𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ].

Consider p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be a polynomial of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ such that 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱))2]≤ϵ′subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscriptsuperscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱2superscriptitalic-ϵ′\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*% }(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilon^{\prime}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ϵ′=ϵ4/Csuperscriptitalic-ϵ′superscriptitalic-ϵ4𝐶\epsilon^{\prime}=\epsilon^{4}/{C}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_C. Since p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approximates a Boolean-valued function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the values of p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should, in expectation, be close to either 1111 or −11-1- 1. In particular, we obtain the following bound using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:

≤ϵ′+2⁢ϵ′≤3⁢ϵ2/Cabsentsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′2superscriptitalic-ϵ′3superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐶\displaystyle\leq\epsilon^{\prime}+\sqrt{2\epsilon^{\prime}}\leq 3\epsilon^{2}% /\sqrt{C}≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG 2 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ 3 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG (4.2)

Note that q⁢(𝐱)=(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1𝑞𝐱superscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21q(\mathbf{x})=(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}-1italic_q ( bold_x ) = ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 is a polynomial of degree at most 2⁢ℓ2ℓ2\ell2 roman_ℓ. Therefore, Algorithm 1 can be used to filter out the points 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x such that q⁢(𝐱)𝑞𝐱q(\mathbf{x})italic_q ( bold_x ) is too large and, in particular, due to Theorem 3.2, the following holds with probability at least 1−δ/41𝛿41-\delta/41 - italic_δ / 4 over the random choice of Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as long as m≥C′⁢(2⁢A⁢(d+1))4⁢ℓϵ6⁢log⁡1δ𝑚superscript𝐶′superscript2𝐴𝑑14ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ61𝛿m\geq C^{\prime}\frac{(2A(d+1))^{4\ell}}{\epsilon^{6}}\log\frac{1}{\delta}italic_m ≥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( 2 italic_A ( italic_d + 1 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG and mref≥(C′⁢A⁢d)4⁢ℓϵ6⁢(log⁡1δ)8⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴𝑑4ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ6superscript1𝛿8ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq\frac{(C^{\prime}Ad)^{4\ell}}{\epsilon^{6}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{8\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

∑𝐱∈Sfiltq⁢(𝐱)≤ϵ2⁢mC′′,subscript𝐱subscript𝑆filt𝑞𝐱superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑚superscript𝐶′′\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}q(\mathbf{x})\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}m}{C^% {\prime\prime}}\,,∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (4.3)

where C′′=C/24superscript𝐶′′𝐶24C^{\prime\prime}=\sqrt{C}/24italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG / 24. We will now show that this bound is sufficient for our purposes.

Consider the quantity P=|S¯filt|m⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]𝑃subscript¯𝑆filt𝑚subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱P=\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y% )\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]italic_P = divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ]. We first bound the quantity P𝑃Pitalic_P by P≤|S¯filt|2⁢m⁢𝔼(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[|y−p^⁢(𝐱)|]𝑃subscript¯𝑆filt2𝑚subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦^𝑝𝐱P\leq\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{2m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{% x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[|y-\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})|]italic_P ≤ divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) | ], where the factor 1/2121/21 / 2 appears due to the fact that the choice of τ^^𝜏\widehat{\tau}over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG is optimal (and a random choice would yield the factor 1/2121/21 / 2 with positive probability, see [68]). Furthermore, we have the following, due to the fact that p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG is optimal among low-degree polynomials for S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to the absolute error.

For the first term, we choose m=|S¯inp|=|S¯cln|𝑚subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆clnm=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|italic_m = | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | and we have 12⁢m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯cln|f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱)|=12⁢𝔼𝐱∼Scln[|f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱)|]12𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆clnsuperscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱12subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}}|f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})|=\frac{1}{2}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}[|f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ]. In order to bound this quantity, we use the fact that Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. samples from a hypercontractive distribution, combining the Marcinkiewicz-Zygmund inequality (which is a generalization of Chebyshev’s inequality to higher moments), hypercontractivity and boundedness of f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain that, as long as m≥1ϵ2⁢(C′⁢A)2⁢ℓ⁢(log⁡(1/δ))2⁢ℓ+1𝑚1superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴2ℓsuperscript1𝛿2ℓ1m\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon^{2}}(C^{\prime}A)^{2\ell}(\log(1/\delta))^{2\ell+1}italic_m ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with probability at least 1−δ/41𝛿41-\delta/41 - italic_δ / 4 over the choice of Sclnsubscript𝑆clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have:

𝔼𝐱∼Scln[|f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|f^{% *}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] ≤𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[|f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱)|]+ϵ/6absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟superscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ6\displaystyle\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|f% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]+\epsilon/6≤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] + italic_ϵ / 6
≤𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[(f∗⁢(𝐱)−p∗⁢(𝐱))2]+ϵ/6absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟superscriptsuperscript𝑓𝐱superscript𝑝𝐱2italic-ϵ6\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{% *}}[(f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]}+\epsilon/6≤ square-root start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG + italic_ϵ / 6
≤ϵ2/C+ϵ/6≤ϵ/3absentsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐶italic-ϵ6italic-ϵ3\displaystyle\leq\epsilon^{2}/\sqrt{C}+\epsilon/6\leq\epsilon/3≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG + italic_ϵ / 6 ≤ italic_ϵ / 3 (4.5)

For the last term in Eq. (4.4), we first use the basic fact that the variance of any random variable is non-negative and hence 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[|p∗⁢(𝐱)|]≤(𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[(p∗⁢(𝐱))2])1/2subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝑝𝐱superscriptsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱212\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]\leq(\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}% \sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}])^{1% /2}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we observe that 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[(p∗⁢(𝐱))2]=𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[q⁢(𝐱)]+1subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱2subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱1\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}% \sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]+1blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] + 1. Overall, we have:

12⁢m⁢∑𝐱∈Sfilt∖Scln|p∗⁢(𝐱)|12𝑚subscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ≤|Sfilt∖Scln|2⁢m(1+𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[q(𝐱)])1/2\displaystyle\leq\frac{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}{2m}\Bigr% {(}{1+\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_% {\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]}\Bigr{)}^{1/2}≤ divide start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG ( 1 + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (4.6)

We will now bound the quantity P′=𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt∖Scln[q⁢(𝐱)]=1|Sfilt∖Scln|⁢∑𝐱∈Sfilt∖Sclnq⁢(𝐱)superscript𝑃′subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱1subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱P^{\prime}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]=\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}q(\mathbf{x})italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x ).

P′superscript𝑃′\displaystyle P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =1|Sfilt∖Scln|⁢∑𝐱∈Sfiltq⁢(𝐱)−1|Sfilt∖Scln|⁢∑𝐱∈Sfilt∩Sclnq⁢(𝐱)absent1subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filt𝑞𝐱1subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱\displaystyle=\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}\sum_{% \mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}q(\mathbf{x})-\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\cap S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}q(\mathbf{x})= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x )
≤(⁢4.3⁢)ϵ2⁢mC′′⁢|Sfilt∖Scln|+1|Sfilt∖Scln|⁢∑𝐱∈Sfilt∩Scln|q⁢(𝐱)|superscriptitalic-(4.3italic-)absentsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑚superscript𝐶′′subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln1subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{equation:fitering-guarantee}}}{{% \leq}}\frac{\epsilon^{2}m}{C^{\prime\prime}|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}|}+\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}\sum_{% \mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\cap S_{\mathrm{cln}}}|q(\mathbf{x})|start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG ≤ end_ARG start_ARG italic_( italic_) end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_q ( bold_x ) |
≤ϵ2⁢mC′′⁢|Sfilt∖Scln|+m|Sfilt∖Scln|⁢𝔼𝐱∼Scln[|q⁢(𝐱)|]absentsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑚superscript𝐶′′subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑚subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱\displaystyle\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}m}{C^{\prime\prime}|S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}+\frac{m}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{% cln}}|}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|q(\mathbf% {x})|]≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_q ( bold_x ) | ] (4.7)

The first inequality in the expression above follows from the guarantee of Eq. (4.3), which is provided by the filtering algorithm. We may now use the Marcinkiewicz-Zygmund inequality once more to obtain that, as long as m≥1ϵ4⁢(C′⁢A)4⁢ℓ⁢(log⁡(1/δ))4⁢ℓ+1𝑚1superscriptitalic-ϵ4superscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴4ℓsuperscript1𝛿4ℓ1m\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon^{4}}(C^{\prime}A)^{4\ell}(\log(1/\delta))^{4\ell+1}italic_m ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with probability at least 1−δ/41𝛿41-\delta/41 - italic_δ / 4, we have:

𝔼𝐱∼Scln[|q⁢(𝐱)|]≤𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[|q⁢(𝐱)|]+ϵ2/C≤ϵ2/C′′,subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆cln𝑞𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟𝑞𝐱superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐶superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝐶′′\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|q(\mathbf{x})|]% \leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|q(\mathbf{x})|% ]+\epsilon^{2}/\sqrt{C}\leq\epsilon^{2}/C^{\prime\prime}\,,blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_q ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_q ( bold_x ) | ] + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where the last inequality follows from Eq. (4.2), the fact that q⁢(𝐱)=(p∗⁢(𝐱))2−1𝑞𝐱superscriptsuperscript𝑝𝐱21q(\mathbf{x})=(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}-1italic_q ( bold_x ) = ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1, and recall that C′′=Csuperscript𝐶′′𝐶C^{\prime\prime}=\sqrt{C}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG. Overall, we obtain the bound P′≤2⁢ϵ2⁢mC′′⁢|Sfilt∖Scln|superscript𝑃′2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑚superscript𝐶′′subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnP^{\prime}\leq\frac{2\epsilon^{2}m}{C^{\prime\prime}|S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG. Note that since for any a≥0𝑎0a\geq 0italic_a ≥ 0 we have 1+a≤1+a1𝑎1𝑎\sqrt{1+a}\leq 1+\sqrt{a}square-root start_ARG 1 + italic_a end_ARG ≤ 1 + square-root start_ARG italic_a end_ARG, by substituting the bound for P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Eq. 12⁢m⁢∑𝐱∈Sfilt∖Scln|p∗⁢(𝐱)|≤|Sfilt∖Scln|2⁢m+ϵC′′/2,12𝑚subscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝑝𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln2𝑚italic-ϵsuperscript𝐶′′2\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}|p% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\leq\frac{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}{2m}+% \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{C^{\prime\prime}/2}}\,,divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ≤ divide start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2 end_ARG end_ARG ,

where we used the fact that |Sfilt∖Scln|≤msubscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑚|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|\leq m| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_m to bound the factor |Sfilt∖Scln|/msubscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆cln𝑚\sqrt{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|/m}square-root start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_m end_ARG in the second term of the above bound by 1111. In total, by choosing C𝐶Citalic_C appropriately large, we have the following bound, where we combine Eq. (4.4), (4.5), and (4.6).

P=1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}≤|S¯filt∖S¯cln|m+2⁢ϵ3,𝑃1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱subscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆cln𝑚2italic-ϵ3P=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}\leq\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|}{m}+\frac{2\epsilon}{3}\,,italic_P = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } ≤ divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ,

with probability at least 1−3⁢δ/413𝛿41-3\delta/41 - 3 italic_δ / 4 over the random choice of S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We will now bound ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦ℎ𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] by 2⁢η+5⁢ϵ/62𝜂5italic-ϵ62\eta+5\epsilon/62 italic_η + 5 italic_ϵ / 6. We have the following:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯cln[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆cln𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% cln}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] =1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯cln𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}absent1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆cln1𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}}% \operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) }
=1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯cln∩S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}+1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯cln∖S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}absent1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar% {S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+\frac{1}% {m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt% }}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) }
≤∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}+|S¯cln∖S¯filt|mabsentsubscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt𝑚\displaystyle\leq\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar% {S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG
≤|S¯filt∖S¯cln|+|(S¯cln∩S¯inp)∖S¯filt|+|S¯cln∖S¯inp|m+2⁢ϵ/3absentsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inp𝑚2italic-ϵ3\displaystyle\leq\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}% |+|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm% {filt}}|+|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|}{m}+2\epsilon/3≤ divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG + 2 italic_ϵ / 3

In order to complete the proof, we use the guarantee of Algorithm 1 that with probability at least 1−δ/41𝛿41-\delta/41 - italic_δ / 4, we have

|(S¯cln∩S¯inp)∖S¯filt|subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt\displaystyle|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus\bar{% S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|| ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤12⁢|S¯inp∖S¯filt|+ϵ⁢m12absent12subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚12\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2}|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{12}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 12 end_ARG
=12⁢|(S¯cln∩S¯inp)∖S¯filt|+12⁢|(S¯inp∖S¯cln)∖S¯filt|+ϵ⁢m/12.absent12subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt12subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚12\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})% \setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|+\frac{1}{2}|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}})\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|+\epsilon m/12\,.= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + italic_ϵ italic_m / 12 .

Therefore, we have |(S¯cln∩S¯inp)∖S¯filt|≤|(S¯inp∖S¯cln)∖S¯filt|+ϵ⁢m/6subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚6|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|\leq|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}})\setminus% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|+\epsilon m/6| ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ | ( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + italic_ϵ italic_m / 6. Note that the union of the sets (S¯inp∖S¯cln)∖S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}})\setminus\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}( over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S¯filt∖S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is disjoint and equals to the set of adversarial examples S¯adv=S¯inp∖S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆advsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}}=\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the definition of the noise model (Definition 1.1), we have that |S¯adv|≤η⁢msubscript¯𝑆adv𝜂𝑚|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}}|\leq\eta m| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_η italic_m and |S¯cln∖S¯inp|=|S¯adv|≤η⁢msubscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆adv𝜂𝑚|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}% }|\leq\eta m| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_η italic_m. Therefore, we overall obtain the desired bound of

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯cln[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤2⁢η+5⁢ϵ6.subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆cln𝑦ℎ𝐱2𝜂5italic-ϵ6\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\frac{5\epsilon}{6}\,.blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ 2 italic_η + divide start_ARG 5 italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG .

This concludes the proof of Theorem 4.2. ∎

4.2 Learning with Heavy Contamination

For heavy contamination, our results are based on the stronger notion of sandwiching approximators from pseudorandomness [3].

Definition 4.3 (Sandwiching Approximators).

For ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_ϵ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } has ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-sandwiching degree ℓ=ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓℓitalic-ϵ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ = roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) with respect to some distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C there are two polynomials pup,pdownsubscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of degree at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) such that:

  1. 1.

    pdown⁢(𝐱)≤f⁢(𝐱)≤pup⁢(𝐱)subscript𝑝down𝐱𝑓𝐱subscript𝑝up𝐱p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})\leq f(\mathbf{x})\leq p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ≤ italic_f ( bold_x ) ≤ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) for all 𝐱∈𝒳𝐱𝒳\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}bold_x ∈ caligraphic_X and

  2. 2.

    𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]≤ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟subscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ italic_ϵ

Once more, our main result requires hypercontractivity of the marginal distribution.

Theorem 4.4 (Sandwiching implies HC-Learning).

Let ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and A,Q≥1𝐴𝑄1A,Q\geq 1italic_A , italic_Q ≥ 1. Let 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some A𝐴Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional space and let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose ϵ2C⁢Qsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐶𝑄\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{CQ}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C italic_Q end_ARG-sandwiching degree w.r.t. 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ for some large enough constant C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1italic_C ≥ 1. Then, there is an algorithm that (ϵ,δ,Q)italic-ϵ𝛿𝑄(\epsilon,\delta,Q)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_Q )-HC learns 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in time poly⁡(Aℓ,(log⁡(1/δ))ℓ,(d+1)ℓ,Q/ϵ)polysuperscript𝐴ℓsuperscript1𝛿ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ𝑄italic-ϵ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log(1/\delta))^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},Q/\epsilon)roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q / italic_ϵ ), and has (clean) sample complexity at most Q2ϵ5⋅O⁢(A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⋅log⁡1δ⋅⋅superscript𝑄2superscriptitalic-ϵ5𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑2ℓ1𝛿\frac{Q^{2}}{\epsilon^{5}}\cdot O(Ad)^{2\ell}\cdot\log\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ italic_O ( italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG.

In Table 3, we provide a number of end-to-end results for learning with heavy contamination, which are obtained by combining Theorem 4.4 with appropriate known bounds on the sandwiching degree (see Section C.2). The first row of Table 3 gives the bound dO~⁢(Q2⁢k6/ϵ4)superscript𝑑~𝑂superscript𝑄2superscript𝑘6superscriptitalic-ϵ4d^{\tilde{O}(Q^{2}k^{6}/\epsilon^{4})}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for learning intersections of k𝑘kitalic_k halfspaces with Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-heavy contamination by choosing s=t=k𝑠𝑡𝑘s=t=kitalic_s = italic_t = italic_k, as well as the bound dO~⁢(Q2⁢k4⁢4k/ϵ4)superscript𝑑~𝑂superscript𝑄2superscript𝑘4superscript4𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ4d^{\tilde{O}(Q^{2}k^{4}4^{k}/\epsilon^{4})}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for arbitrary functions of k𝑘kitalic_k halfspaces, with the choice s=2k𝑠superscript2𝑘s=2^{k}italic_s = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, t=k𝑡𝑘t=kitalic_t = italic_k.

The proof of Theorem 4.4 uses once more Algorithm 1 to filter the input set, but this time we set the hyperparameter R𝑅Ritalic_R to a value that scales with the heavy contamination ratio Q𝑄Qitalic_Q. This ensures that we keep most of the clean points, because the filtering process is highly selective. Due to the choice of R𝑅Ritalic_R, the required sandwiching degree scales with Q𝑄Qitalic_Q as well. As a consequence, for many classes, our bounds are exponential in Q𝑄Qitalic_Q. After filtering, the approximation property of the sandwiching polynomials is preserved under the empirical distribution over the filtered set, and this is sufficient for efficient learnability of the optimum hypothesis on the filtered set, due to Theorem A.3 by [68]. We give the full proof of our main result on learning with heavy contamination (Theorem 4.4) below.

Proof of Theorem 4.4.

The algorithm receives a Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-heavily contaminated dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, draws a set Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=Q2⁢(C′⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓϵ5⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscript𝑄2superscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ5superscript1𝛿4ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{Q^{2}(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{5}}(\log\frac{1}% {\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where C′≥1superscript𝐶′1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of Theorem 3.2 (that is, Algorithm 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=Q2⁢(C′⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⁢log⁡1δϵ5,ℓ,R=2⁢Qϵ,ϵ/3)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆ref𝑚superscript𝑄2superscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴𝑑2ℓ1𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ5ℓ𝑅2𝑄italic-ϵitalic-ϵ3(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=\frac{Q^{2}(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}\log% \frac{1}{\delta}}{\epsilon^{5}},\ell,R=\frac{2Q}{\epsilon},\epsilon/3)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , roman_ℓ , italic_R = divide start_ARG 2 italic_Q end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG , italic_ϵ / 3 ) to form the filtered dataset S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ that minimizes the following convex objective.

    p^=arg⁡minp^𝑝subscript𝑝\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 𝔼(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[|y−p⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]
    s.t. p⁢ has degree at most ⁢ℓ𝑝 has degree at most ℓ\displaystyle p\text{ has degree at most }\ellitalic_p has degree at most roman_ℓ
  3. 3.

    The algorithm outputs h⁢(𝐱)=sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ^)ℎ𝐱sign^𝑝𝐱^𝜏h(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ), where τ^∈ℝ^𝜏ℝ\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦sign^𝑝𝐱𝜏\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_τ ) ] over τ∈ℝ𝜏ℝ\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_τ ∈ blackboard_R.

We will now bound the error of hℎhitalic_h on the clean distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. To this end, we first note that the empirical error of hℎhitalic_h on the clean samples S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is, with high probability, close to the error on 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, since |S¯cln|subscript¯𝑆cln|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | is large enough and hℎhitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. It therefore, suffices to bound the error of hℎhitalic_h on S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have the following.

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯cln[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆cln𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% cln}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] =1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∼S¯cln∩S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}+1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∼S¯cln∖S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}absent1𝑚subscriptsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱1𝑚subscriptsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+% \frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) }
≤1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}+1m⋅|S¯cln∖S¯filt|absent1𝑚subscriptsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱⋅1𝑚subscript¯𝑆clnsubscript¯𝑆filt\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}% \operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+\frac{1}{m}\cdot|\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ⋅ | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (4.8)

The second term in the bound above can be bounded by ϵ/3italic-ϵ3\epsilon/3italic_ϵ / 3, due to part 1 of Theorem 3.2. It remains to bound the first term.

Consider f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C to be the concept in class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with minimum error on S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., we have that f∗=arg⁡minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]superscript𝑓subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙ𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦𝑓𝐱f^{*}=\arg\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ]. Note that there is some f′∈𝒞superscript𝑓′𝒞f^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C that makes at most M⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total⋅𝑀subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalM\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_M ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT errors on the whole input dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, due to the definition of 𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Definition 1.4). We have that ℙ(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]≤ℙ(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt[y≠f′⁢(𝐱)]≤M⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total/|S¯filt|subscriptℙ𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱subscriptℙ𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦superscript𝑓′𝐱⋅𝑀subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript¯𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f^% {*}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f^{\prime}(\mathbf{x})]\leq{M}\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm% {total}}/{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ italic_M ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |.

Moreover, let pup,pdownsubscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the ϵ272⁢Qsuperscriptitalic-ϵ272𝑄\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{72Q}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 72 italic_Q end_ARG-sandwiching polynomials for f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and p=pup−pdown𝑝subscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp=p_{\mathrm{up}}-p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a non-negative polynomial with 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[|p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ272⁢Qsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱superscriptitalic-ϵ272𝑄\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \frac{\epsilon^{2}}{72Q}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 72 italic_Q end_ARG. Due to part 2 of Theorem 3.2, the expectation of p𝑝pitalic_p under Sfiltsubscript𝑆filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most ϵ⁢m3⁢|S¯filt|italic-ϵ𝑚3subscript¯𝑆filt\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG, i.e., 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]≤ϵ⁢m3⁢|S¯filt|subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚3subscript¯𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}|}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG. Since pup≥f∗≥pdownsubscript𝑝upsuperscript𝑓subscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}}\geq f^{*}\geq p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we also have that

𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[|f∗⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵ⁢m3⁢|S¯filt|subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsuperscript𝑓𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚3subscript¯𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[|f^{*}(\mathbf{x% })-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG

We now observe that hℎhitalic_h is the output of the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression algorithm on S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, therefore, according to Theorem A.3 by [68], we overall have the following bound

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤M|S¯filt|⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+ϵ⁢m3⁢|S¯filt|,subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱⋅𝑀subscript¯𝑆filtsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalitalic-ϵ𝑚3subscript¯𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{M}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm% {total}}+\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\,,blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ,

which implies the desired bound:

1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}≤Mm⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+ϵ⁢m2≤Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+ϵ/31𝑚subscriptsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱⋅𝑀𝑚subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalitalic-ϵ𝑚2⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalitalic-ϵ3\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}\leq\frac{M}{m}\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{% total}}+\frac{\epsilon m}{2}\leq Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\epsilon/3divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } ≤ divide start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ≤ italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ / 3 (4.9)

The result follows by combining Eq. (4.8) and (4.9). ∎

Remark 4.5.

Our result on HC-learning highlights the following analogy:

  • •

    Learning with heavy contamination can be thought of as a version of testable agnostic learning (Definition 4.7), where the algorithm is asked to find a subset of the input that is structured enough, instead of merely verifying whether the whole input is structured.

  • •

    Similarly, in the context of learning with distribution shift, PQ learning [49] requires finding a subset of an unlabeled test dataset where the learner is confident in its own predictions, while TDS learning [78] aims to verify whether the whole unlabeled test dataset is drawn from some distribution that is similar to the one the learner has trained on.

  • •

    In [54], it is shown that by using a spectral iterative filtering algorithm, TDS learning results can be extended to PQ learning. Here, we complete the analogy by showing that our iterative filtering algorithm can extend known results from testable learning (i.e., that sandwiching is sufficient, see [48]) to HC-learning.

Remark 4.6.

One could define a hybrid model where a bounded fraction of clean points are replaced adversarially and a proportionally large number of adversarial points are then added. Our results should apply to this setting as well, but we focus on BC and HC learning separately for simplicity of presentation.

4.3 Tolerant Testable Learning

We give new results for testable learning [83] and tolerant testable learning [54].

Definition 4.7 (Tolerant Testable Learning [54]).

An algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is a tolerant tester-learner for 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } with respect to some target distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if on input (ϵ,δ,τ,S¯inp)italic-ϵ𝛿𝜏subscript¯𝑆inp(\epsilon,\delta,\tau,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_τ , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ϵ,τ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝜏𝛿01\epsilon,\tau,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_τ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a set of i.i.d. examples from some arbitrary distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs either outputs RejectReject\mathrm{Reject}roman_Reject or outputs (Accept,h)Acceptℎ(\mathrm{Accept},h)( roman_Accept , italic_h ), where h:𝒳→{±1}:ℎ→𝒳plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } such that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, the following conditions hold.

  1. 1.

    (Soundness) Upon acceptance, the error of hℎhitalic_h is bounded as follows:

    ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]+τ+ϵsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦ℎ𝐱subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱𝜏italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},% y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]+\tau+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] + italic_τ + italic_ϵ
  2. 2.

    (Completeness) If dTV⁢(𝒟,𝒟∗)≤τsubscriptdTV𝒟superscript𝒟𝜏\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{TV}}(\mathcal{D},{\mathcal{D}^{*}})\leq\tauroman_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_TV end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_τ, where 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is the marginal of 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, then 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A accepts.

The sample complexity of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee.

Previous work by [54] showed that the existence of ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching polynomials with bounded coefficients, i.e., polynomials pup,pdownsubscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[(pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱))2]≤ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱2italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[(p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_ϵ implies tolerant testable learning. Here, we relax this condition to ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching polynomials (Definition 4.3), without requiring any bound on the coefficients. Note that even for non-tolerant testable learning, where ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching is known to suffice [48], all prior work required bounds on the coefficients.

Theorem 4.8 (Sandwiching implies Tolerant Testable Learning).

Let ϵ,δ,τ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿𝜏01\epsilon,\delta,\tau\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_τ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and Q≥1𝑄1Q\geq 1italic_Q ≥ 1. Let 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some A𝐴Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional space and let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose ϵC⁢(1+τ/ϵ)italic-ϵ𝐶1𝜏italic-ϵ\frac{\epsilon}{C(1+\tau/\epsilon)}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_C ( 1 + italic_τ / italic_ϵ ) end_ARG-sandwiching degree w.r.t. 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ for some large enough constant C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1italic_C ≥ 1. Then, there is an (ϵ,δ,τ)italic-ϵ𝛿𝜏(\epsilon,\delta,\tau)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_τ )-tester-learner for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C w.r.t. 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with runtime poly⁡(Aℓ,(log⁡(1/δ))ℓ,(d+1)ℓ,1/ϵ)polysuperscript𝐴ℓsuperscript1𝛿ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ1italic-ϵ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log(1/\delta))^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},1/\epsilon)roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1 / italic_ϵ ), and sample complexity at most 1ϵ5⋅O⁢(A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⋅log⁡1δ⋅⋅1superscriptitalic-ϵ5𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑2ℓ1𝛿\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5}}\cdot O(Ad)^{2\ell}\cdot\log\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ italic_O ( italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG.

The following corollary follows from Theorem 4.8, combined with the fact that log-concave distributions are hypercontractive (see [10]), as well as the results of [73, 67] on the sandwiching degree of functions of halfspaces (see Section C.2). This is the first result for testably learning even a single halfspace with respect to log-concave distributions up to optimal error.

Corollary 4.9.

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be the class of arbitrary functions of k𝑘kitalic_k halfspaces over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and let 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be any log-concave distribution. There is an (ϵ,δ,τ)italic-ϵ𝛿𝜏(\epsilon,\delta,\tau)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , italic_τ )-tester-learner for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that runs in time (d⁢log⁡(1/δ))O~⁢(ℓ)superscript𝑑1𝛿~𝑂ℓ(d\log(1/\delta))^{\tilde{O}(\ell)}( italic_d roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_ℓ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ℓ=exp⁡((log⁡(log⁡(k)/ϵ))O⁢(k)/ϵ8)ℓsuperscript𝑘italic-ϵ𝑂𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ8\ell=\exp((\log(\log(k)/\epsilon))^{O(k)}/\epsilon^{8})roman_ℓ = roman_exp ( ( roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_ϵ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We will now prove Theorem 4.8, using once more the iterative polynomial filtering algorithm of Theorem 3.2.

Proof of Theorem 4.8.

The algorithm receives a dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, draws a reference set Srefsubscript𝑆refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=(C′⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓϵ5⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1subscript𝑚refsuperscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϵ5superscript1𝛿4ℓ1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{5}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, where C′≥1superscript𝐶′1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of Theorem 3.2 (that is, Algorithm 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=|Sinp|,ℓ,R=4⁢τϵ+2,ϵ/8)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆ref𝑚subscript𝑆inpℓ𝑅4𝜏italic-ϵ2italic-ϵ8(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,\ell,R=\frac{4\tau}{% \epsilon}+{2},\epsilon/8)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , roman_ℓ , italic_R = divide start_ARG 4 italic_τ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG + 2 , italic_ϵ / 8 ) to form the filtered dataset S¯filtsubscript¯𝑆filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm checks if m−|S¯filt|≤(τ+ϵ/2)⁢m𝑚subscript¯𝑆filt𝜏italic-ϵ2𝑚m-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq(\tau+\epsilon/2)mitalic_m - | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 2 ) italic_m and rejects if the inequality does not hold.

  3. 3.

    Otherwise, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^𝑝\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ that minimizes the following convex objective.
