    p^=arg⁡minp^𝑝subscript𝑝\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 𝔼(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[|y−p⁢(𝐱)|]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦𝑝𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]
    s.t. p⁢ has degree at most ⁢ℓ𝑝 has degree at most ℓ\displaystyle p\text{ has degree at most }\ellitalic_p has degree at most roman_ℓ
  4. 4.

    The algorithm outputs h⁢(𝐱)=sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ^)ℎ𝐱sign^𝑝𝐱^𝜏h(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ), where τ^∈ℝ^𝜏ℝ\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠sign⁡(p^⁢(𝐱)+τ)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦sign^𝑝𝐱𝜏\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_τ ) ] over τ∈ℝ𝜏ℝ\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_τ ∈ blackboard_R.

Soundness.

Suppose, first, that the algorithm accepts. Observe that |S¯inp∖S¯filt|=|S¯inp|−|S¯filt|subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp% }}|-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, since S¯filt⊆S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\subseteq\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the algorithm has accepted, we know the following.

|S¯inp|−|S¯filt|=m−|S¯filt|≤m⁢(τ+ϵ/2)subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt𝑚subscript¯𝑆filt𝑚𝜏italic-ϵ2|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=m-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|% \leq m(\tau+\epsilon/2)| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = italic_m - | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_m ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 2 )

Recall that S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. examples from the input distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Since m𝑚mitalic_m is large enough, due to standard VC dimension arguments (and the fact that hℎhitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ), we have that with high probability:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]+ϵ/4subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦ℎ𝐱subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦ℎ𝐱italic-ϵ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm% {inp}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]+\epsilon/4blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] + italic_ϵ / 4 (4.10)

Therefore, it suffices to show a bound on the empirical error of hℎhitalic_h on S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have the following:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% inp}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] =1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯inp∖S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}+1m⁢∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯filt𝟙⁡{y≠h⁢(𝐱)}absent1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱1𝑚subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt1𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}% \setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x% })\}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) }
≤1m⁢|S¯inp∖S¯filt|+|S¯filt|m⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]absent1𝑚subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆filt𝑚subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{m}|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|+\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(% \mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ]
≤τ+ϵ2+|S¯filt|m⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]absent𝜏italic-ϵ2subscript¯𝑆filt𝑚subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱\displaystyle\leq\tau+\frac{\epsilon}{2}+\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]≤ italic_τ + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ]

It suffices to show that ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤m|S¯filt|⁢(minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]+ϵ/4)subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱𝑚subscript¯𝑆filtsubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦ℎ𝐱italic-ϵ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{m}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}(\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]+\epsilon/4)blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ( roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] + italic_ϵ / 4 ). Let f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the function that minimizes the error on 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG and let pup,pdownsubscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be its ϵ2128⁢τ+64⁢ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2128𝜏64italic-ϵ\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{128\tau+64\epsilon}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 128 italic_τ + 64 italic_ϵ end_ARG-sandwiching polynomials. Then according to part 2 of Theorem 3.2, and since for p=pup−pdown𝑝subscript𝑝upsubscript𝑝downp=p_{\mathrm{up}}-p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[p⁢(𝐱)]≤ϵ2128⁢τ+64⁢ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱superscriptitalic-ϵ2128𝜏64italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[p(\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac% {\epsilon^{2}}{128\tau+64\epsilon}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 128 italic_τ + 64 italic_ϵ end_ARG, we obtain:

|Sfilt|⁢𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]=∑𝐱∈Sfilt(pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱))≤ϵ⁢m8subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱subscript𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚8|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}% }}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]=\sum_{\mathbf{x}% \in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}(p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x% }))\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{8}| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG

Therefore, we also have 𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[|f∗⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)|]≤𝔼𝐱∼Sfilt[pup⁢(𝐱)−pdown⁢(𝐱)]≤ϵ⁢m8⁢|Sfilt|subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsuperscript𝑓𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑝up𝐱subscript𝑝down𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚8subscript𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[|f^{*}(\mathbf{x% })-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}% \sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{% x})]\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{8|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG. Observe, now that hℎhitalic_h is the output of the low-degree polynomial regression algorithm and, hence, according to Theorem A.3 by [68], we have the following.

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]+ϵ⁢m8⁢|S¯filt|subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦ℎ𝐱subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ𝑚8subscript¯𝑆filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f^{*}(\mathbf{x})]+\frac{\epsilon m}{8|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG

To conclude the argument, observe ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯filt[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]≤m|S¯filt|⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆filt𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱𝑚subscript¯𝑆filtsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{m}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\operatorname*{\mathbb% {P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq f^{*}(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ], since S¯filt⊆S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆filtsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\subseteq\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, due to a Hoeffding bound, with high probability we have ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]≤ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f∗⁢(𝐱)]+ϵ/8subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦superscript𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ8\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq f^% {*}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{% \mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f^{*}(\mathbf{x})]+\epsilon/8blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] ≤ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] + italic_ϵ / 8. Note that due to the choice of f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f∗(𝐱)]=minf∈𝒞ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f(𝐱)]=:𝗈𝗉𝗍\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f^{*}(% \mathbf{x})]=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)% \sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]=:\mathsf{opt}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = : sansserif_opt. Overall, we have the following bound:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤𝗈𝗉𝗍+τ+3⁢ϵ/4,subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦ℎ𝐱𝗈𝗉𝗍𝜏3italic-ϵ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\mathsf{opt}+\tau+3\epsilon/4\,,blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ sansserif_opt + italic_τ + 3 italic_ϵ / 4 ,

which, together with the generalization bound of Eq. (4.10) implies the soundness of the algorithm.

Completeness.

We will now show that the algorithm accepts with high probability whenever dTV⁢(𝒟,𝒟∗)≤τsubscriptdTV𝒟superscript𝒟𝜏\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{TV}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{*})\leq\tauroman_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_TV end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_τ. It suffices to show that |S¯inp∖S¯filt|≤(τ+ϵ/2)⁢msubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt𝜏italic-ϵ2𝑚|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq(\tau+\epsilon/2)m| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 2 ) italic_m with high probability, since |S¯inp∖S¯filt|=m−|S¯filt|subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt𝑚subscript¯𝑆filt|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=m-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = italic_m - | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, which is exactly the quantity based upon which the algorithm decides whether to reject or not.

Let Scln={𝐱(1),𝐱(2),…,𝐱(m)}subscript𝑆clnsuperscript𝐱1superscript𝐱2…superscript𝐱𝑚S_{\mathrm{cln}}=\{\mathbf{x}^{(1)},\mathbf{x}^{(2)},\dots,\mathbf{x}^{(m)}\}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } be a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. examples drawn from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. Let Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be drawn as follows:

  • •

    For each i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ], draw an independent Bernoulli random variable ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with success rate 1−τ1𝜏1-\tau1 - italic_τ.

  • •

    If ξi=1subscript𝜉𝑖1\xi_{i}=1italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, then let 𝐳(i)=𝐱(i)superscript𝐳𝑖superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{z}^{(i)}=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • •

    If ξi=0subscript𝜉𝑖0\xi_{i}=0italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, then draw 𝐳(i)superscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}^{(i)}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT independently from the residual distribution 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the maximal coupling between 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., the joint distribution (𝐱,𝐱∗)𝐱superscript𝐱(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{*})( bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) that has marginals 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively and maximizes the likelihood that 𝐱=𝐱∗𝐱superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}^{*}bold_x = bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

  • •

    Let Scln={𝐳(i)}i∈[m]subscript𝑆clnsubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚S_{\mathrm{cln}}=\{\mathbf{z}^{(i)}\}_{i\in[m]}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that the distribution of each 𝐳(i)superscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}^{(i)}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and they are drawn independently. Due to a Chernoff bound, since m𝑚mitalic_m is large enough, we have that, with high probability, |Sinp∖Scln|≤m⁢(τ+ϵ/8)subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆cln𝑚𝜏italic-ϵ8|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|\leq m(\tau+\epsilon/8)| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_m ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 8 ). According to Theorem 3.2, we have the following, with high probability:

|(Sinp∩Scln)∖Sfilt|subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝑆filt\displaystyle|(S_{\mathrm{inp}}\cap S_{\mathrm{cln}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt% }}|| ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤1R⋅|Sinp∖Sfilt|+ϵ⁢m8absent⋅1𝑅subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filtitalic-ϵ𝑚8\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{R}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|% +\frac{\epsilon m}{8}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ⋅ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG

Observe, now, that |Sinp∖Sfilt|=|(Sinp∩Scln)∖Sfilt|+|Sinp∖Scln|subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆clnsubscript𝑆filtsubscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆cln|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|=|(S_{\mathrm{inp}}\cap S_{% \mathrm{cln}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|+|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}|| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Therefore, if we solve for |Sinp∖Sfilt|subscript𝑆inpsubscript𝑆filt|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, we have the following

(1−1R)⋅|Sinp∖Sfilt|≤|Sinp∖Scln|+ϵ⁢m8≤m(τ+ϵ/4)\Bigr{(}1-\frac{1}{R}\Bigr{)}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}% |\leq|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{8}\leq m(% \tau+\epsilon/4)( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ) ⋅ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ≤ italic_m ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 4 )

Due to the choice of R𝑅Ritalic_R, we have the desired bound |S¯inp∖S¯filt|≤m⁢(τ+ϵ/2)subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆filt𝑚𝜏italic-ϵ2|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq m(\tau+\epsilon/2)| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_m ( italic_τ + italic_ϵ / 2 ). ∎

5 Lower Bounds for Learning with Contamination

5.1 Bounded Contamination

Although the problem of learning from contaminated datasets is, in principle, more challenging than learning with label noise, it is not clear whether the common formulations of the former are formally stronger than those of the latter. In particular, the problem of learning with label noise is usually formalized in terms of agnostic learning, where the goal is to achieve error 𝗈𝗉𝗍+ϵ𝗈𝗉𝗍italic-ϵ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_ϵ on the input distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG for 𝗈𝗉𝗍=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]𝗈𝗉𝗍subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱\mathsf{opt}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)% \sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ], where 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is the learned class. In contrast, learning with contamination is usually formulated as learning with nasty noise, where the goal is to achieve error 2⁢η+ϵ2𝜂italic-ϵ2\eta+\epsilon2 italic_η + italic_ϵ on the target distribution (𝒟∗,f∗)superscript𝒟superscript𝑓(\mathcal{D}^{*},f^{*})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C and η𝜂\etaitalic_η is the noise rate. Therefore, given an algorithm for learning with contamination, one may obtain an agnostic learner with error guarantee 3⁢𝗈𝗉𝗍+ϵ3𝗈𝗉𝗍italic-ϵ3\mathsf{opt}+\epsilon3 sansserif_opt + italic_ϵ, but it is not clear whether the guarantee of 𝗈𝗉𝗍+ϵ𝗈𝗉𝗍italic-ϵ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_ϵ can be achieved in a black-box way. This is because in one formulation the error is measured with respect to the input distribution and in the other it is measured with respect to the clean target distribution.

Furthermore, many of the lower bounds for agnostic learning seem to exclusively rule out algorithms with error guarantees of 𝗈𝗉𝗍+ϵ𝗈𝗉𝗍italic-ϵ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_ϵ [37]. Therefore, these lower bounds do not transfer directly to learning with bounded contamination as defined in Definition 1.1. One natural way to go around this, is to observe that our result in Theorem 4.2 would also hold for the following stronger version of Definition 1.1.

Definition 5.1 (Agnostic BC-Learning).

An algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is an agnostic BC-learner for 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } if on input (ϵ,δ,S¯inp)italic-ϵ𝛿subscript¯𝑆inp(\epsilon,\delta,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), and S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG with bounded contamination η𝜂\etaitalic_η for some labeled distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, and η∈[0,1)𝜂01\eta\in[0,1)italic_η ∈ [ 0 , 1 ), the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:𝒳→{±1}:ℎ→𝒳plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } such that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over the clean examples in S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤2⁢η+𝗈𝗉𝗍clean+ϵ, where ⁢𝗈𝗉𝗍clean=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]formulae-sequencesubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦ℎ𝐱2𝜂subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleanitalic-ϵ where subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleansubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}+\epsilon\,,\text{ where }% \mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ 2 italic_η + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ , where sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ]

The sample complexity of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee. Moreover, a distribution-specific BC-learner with respect to some distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟{\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is a BC-learner that is guaranteed to work only when 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}={\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note that Definition 5.1 is a generalization of agnostic learning, since one can obtain agnostic learning by setting η=0𝜂0\eta=0italic_η = 0. Our Theorem 4.2 holds even under this definition, and all the lower bounds for agnostic learning (Table 4) are also inherited. For example, our results indicate that a runtime of dpoly⁡(1ϵ,log⁡k)superscript𝑑poly1italic-ϵ𝑘d^{\operatorname{poly}(\frac{1}{\epsilon},\log k)}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_poly ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG , roman_log italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is both sufficient and necessary for learning intersections of k𝑘kitalic_k halfspaces in the agnostic BC setting. However, agnostic learning is known to be characterized by the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximate degree [68, 42, 37], whereas we require the stronger assumption of low ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximate degree. Therefore, while for most interesting classes our results are essentially tight, a complete characterization of efficient learnability in the setting of Definition 5.1 remains open.

5.2 Heavy Contamination

We provide an information-theoretic lower bound for learning monotone functions with heavy contamination. Our lower bound highlights a separation between bounded and heavy contamination and justifies the need for a stronger notion of approximation than standard polynomial approximators. In particular, monotone functions over {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are known to admit ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate polynomials of degree ℓ⁢(ϵ)=d/ϵℓitalic-ϵ𝑑italic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)=\sqrt{d}/\epsilonroman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) = square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_ϵ, and hence admit a BC-learner that runs in time 2O⁢(d)superscript2𝑂𝑑2^{{O}(\sqrt{d})}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for ϵ=1/4italic-ϵ14\epsilon=1/4italic_ϵ = 1 / 4, but we show that every HC learner requires 2Ω⁢(d)superscript2Ω𝑑2^{\Omega(d)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ω ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples (and runtime).

Theorem 5.2 (Lower Bound for HC-Learning of Monotone Functions).

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be the class of monotone functions over {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Any HC-learner for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to the uniform distribution over the hypercube Unif⁡({±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) requires sample complexity 2Ω⁢(d)superscript2Ω𝑑2^{\Omega(d)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ω ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even when ϵ=1/4italic-ϵ14\epsilon=1/4italic_ϵ = 1 / 4, Q=2𝑄2Q=2italic_Q = 2 and δ=1/3𝛿13\delta=1/3italic_δ = 1 / 3.

Proof of Theorem 5.2.

Suppose that the ground truth is a constant function, i.e., either f∗≡1superscript𝑓1f^{*}\equiv 1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≡ 1 or f∗≡−1superscript𝑓1f^{*}\equiv-1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≡ - 1, and that m≤2d/10/10𝑚superscript2𝑑1010m\leq 2^{d/10}/10italic_m ≤ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 10. Then, the adversary receives the m𝑚mitalic_m clean examples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and draws m𝑚mitalic_m additional i.i.d. examples S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from Unif⁡({±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), labeling them according to −f∗superscript𝑓-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The input dataset is S¯inp=S¯cln∪S¯′subscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆clnsuperscript¯𝑆′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}=\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note, first, that no algorithm can achieve error better than 1/2121/21 / 2 with probability at least 1/2121/21 / 2, since guessing f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT randomly is an optimal strategy because the distribution of the input dataset S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is exactly the same in the two cases corresponding to f∗≡−1superscript𝑓1f^{*}\equiv-1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≡ - 1 and f∗≡1superscript𝑓1f^{*}\equiv 1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≡ 1. We will show that Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total=0⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total0Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=0italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 with high probability over the choice of S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Let 𝐱,𝐱′𝐱superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two independent samples from Unif⁡({±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We say that 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x and 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are comparable if 𝐱≤𝐱′𝐱superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}\leq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x ≤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or 𝐱′≤𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\leq\mathbf{x}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ bold_x, i.e., if 𝐱⁢(i)≤𝐱′⁢(i)𝐱𝑖superscript𝐱′𝑖\mathbf{x}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)bold_x ( italic_i ) ≤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) for all i𝑖iitalic_i or 𝐱′⁢(i)≤𝐱⁢(i)superscript𝐱′𝑖𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}(i)bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ≤ bold_x ( italic_i ) for all i𝑖iitalic_i. Since the coordinates are independent, we have

ℙ𝐱,𝐱′[𝐱⁢(i)≤𝐱′⁢(i), for all ⁢i∈[d]]=∏i∈[d]ℙ𝐱,𝐱′[𝐱⁢(i)≤𝐱′⁢(i)]=(3/4)dsubscriptℙ𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱𝑖superscript𝐱′𝑖 for all 𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptproduct𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptℙ𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱𝑖superscript𝐱′𝑖superscript34𝑑\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\leq% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\,,\text{ for all }i\in[d]]=\prod_{i\in[d]}\operatorname% *{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}^{% \prime}(i)]=(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) ≤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , for all italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] ] = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) ≤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ] = ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Similarly, for the other direction we have that ℙ𝐱,𝐱′[𝐱⁢(i)≥𝐱′⁢(i), for all ⁢i∈[d]]≤(3/4)dsubscriptℙ𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱𝑖superscript𝐱′𝑖 for all 𝑖delimited-[]𝑑superscript34𝑑\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\geq% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\,,\text{ for all }i\in[d]]\leq(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) ≥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , for all italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] ] ≤ ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and, overall, that ℙ𝐱,𝐱′[𝐱,𝐱′⁢ are comparable]≤2⋅(3/4)dsubscriptℙ𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱superscript𝐱′ are comparable⋅2superscript34𝑑\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x},\mathbf% {x}^{\prime}\text{ are comparable}]\leq 2\cdot(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are comparable ] ≤ 2 ⋅ ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We have a set S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 2⁢m2𝑚2m2 italic_m examples. It suffices to show that no pair of examples in Sinpsubscript𝑆inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is comparable, because, then, any labeling of these examples is consistent with some monotone function and, hence, 𝗈𝗉𝗍total=0subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. We overall have at most 4⁢m24superscript𝑚24m^{2}4 italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pairs and each of them is comparable with probability at most 2⋅(3/4)d⋅2superscript34𝑑2\cdot(3/4)^{d}2 ⋅ ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, by a union bound, the probability that there is a pair that is comparable is at most 8⁢m2⁢(3/4)d≤1/108superscript𝑚2superscript34𝑑1108m^{2}(3/4)^{d}\leq 1/108 italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ 1 / 10. ∎

6 Discussion

In this work, we lay the groundwork for a systematic study of efficient learning algorithms in the presence of contamination. For bounded contamination, we showed that low-degree appriximators suffice, nearly matching the best upper bounds for learning under label noise—a significantly milder noise model. Our results capture the challenging setting of heavy contamination as well, for classes with low sandwiching degree. Central to our approach is the iterative polynomial filtering algorithm, which is related to outlier removal procedures with a long history in the literature of robust learning and optimization (see [72, 38, 29, 30, 54, 79] and references therein). There are several interesting directions for future work:

  1. 1.

    Universality: Our algorithms require samples from the target unlabeled distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Relaxing this requirement and obtaining algorithms that work universally with respect to broad classes of distributions is an important question. This is known to be possible for several problems in learning with label noise [11, 1, 41], robust unsupervised learning [75, 76, 26], as well as testable learning [50, 18].

  2. 2.

    Characterization of Efficient Learnability under Contamination: We show that ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial approximation suffices for efficient BC-learning and ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching suffices for efficient HC-learning. Determining whether the weaker notion of ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is sufficient for BC-learning or relaxing the sandwiching requirement for HC-learning are both interesting open directions for future work.

  3. 3.

    Improved Error Guarantees: Our algorithms obtain error guarantees that are proven to be optimal in general (see Proposition B.3). However, it is an open question whether one can achieve error η+ϵ𝜂italic-ϵ\eta+\epsilonitalic_η + italic_ϵ for BC-learning or error 12⁢(Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+𝗈𝗉𝗍clean)+ϵ12⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleanitalic-ϵ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}})+\epsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_ϵ for HC-learning for special classes and distributions, perhaps by allowing the learner to output randomized hypotheses (also known as probabilistic concepts).

  4. 4.

    Heavy Contamination without Label Noise: Our definition for learning with heavy contamination allows the adversary to add arbitrary labeled examples, as long as the resulting contaminated dataset can be approximately labeled by some classifier in the learned class up to a small number of mistakes. Note that the optimal classifier can also be chosen adversarially, in the sense that we do not require that the optimal classifier for the contaminated dataset be the same as the optimal classifier on the clean distribution. This property is crucially used in our lower bound for learning monotone functions with heavy contamination (Theorem 5.2): the hard instance is perfectly labeled by some monotone function, but this monotone function is far from the one that generates the clean labels.

    On the other hand, even in the realizable HC setting—where the clean labels are given by some concept f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C and the adversary is required to add points of the form (𝐱,f∗⁢(𝐱))𝐱superscript𝑓𝐱(\mathbf{x},f^{*}(\mathbf{x}))( bold_x , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) )—it is not clear when efficient learning is possible. This is because for many classes, the assumptions on the distribution of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x are crucial, even in the absence of label noise. It is therefore an interesting open question whether improved HC-learning guarantees can be achieved in the realizable setting.

  • KKMS [08] Adam Tauman Kalai, Adam R Klivans, Yishay Mansour, and Rocco A Servedio. Agnostically learning halfspaces. SIAM Journal on Computing, 37(6):1777–1805, 2008.
  • KL [93] Michael J. Kearns and Ming Li. Learning in the presence of malicious errors. SIAM J. Comput., 22(4):807–837, 1993.
  • KLL+ [23] Jonathan Kelner, Jerry Li, Allen X. Liu, Aaron Sidford, and Kevin Tian. Semi-random sparse recovery in nearly-linear time.
