Appendix A Additional Tools

In our proofs, we make use of the following results for hypercontractive distributions.

Lemma A.1 (Loewner Concentration, Lemma 3.8 in [19], Lemma B.1 in [54]).

Let 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be some A𝐴Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution in d𝑑ditalic_d dimensions and let S𝑆Sitalic_S be a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. examples from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D where m≥(C⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1𝑚superscript𝐶𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscript1𝛿4ℓ1m\geq(CAd)^{2\ell}(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m ≥ ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some sufficiently large universal constant C≥1𝐶1C\geq 1italic_C ≥ 1, δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and A,ℓ,d≥1𝐴ℓ𝑑1A,\ell,d\geq 1italic_A , roman_ℓ , italic_d ≥ 1. Then, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over S𝑆Sitalic_S the following condition holds.

12⁢𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤𝔼𝐱∼S[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤2⁢𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(p⁢(𝐱))2], for any ⁢p⁢ of degree at most ⁢ℓformulae-sequence12subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑝𝐱2subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱22subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑝𝐱2 for any 𝑝 of degree at most ℓ\frac{1}{2}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq 2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\,,\,\text{ for any }p\text{ of degree at most }\elldivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , for any italic_p of degree at most roman_ℓ
Lemma A.2.

Let 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be some A𝐴{A}italic_A-hypercontractive distribution in d𝑑ditalic_d dimensions for some A≥1𝐴1A\geq 1italic_A ≥ 1. Let S𝑆Sitalic_S be a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. samples from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and 𝒫β⁢(S)subscript𝒫𝛽𝑆\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) be the family of polynomials of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ such that 𝔼𝐱∼S[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤βsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱2𝛽\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_β, where ℓ,β,d≥1ℓ𝛽𝑑1\ell,\beta,d\geq 1roman_ℓ , italic_β , italic_d ≥ 1. Then, for any ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_ϵ , italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), if m≥(C⁢A⁢d)2⁢ℓ⁢(log⁡1δ)4⁢ℓ+1𝑚superscript𝐶𝐴𝑑2ℓsuperscript1𝛿4ℓ1m\geq(CAd)^{2\ell}(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m ≥ ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and B≥2⁢β/ϵ⋅(d+1)ℓ/2𝐵⋅2𝛽italic-ϵsuperscript𝑑1ℓ2B\geq\sqrt{{2\beta}/{\epsilon}}\cdot(d+1)^{\ell/2}italic_B ≥ square-root start_ARG 2 italic_β / italic_ϵ end_ARG ⋅ ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the following holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over S𝑆Sitalic_S:

ℙ𝐱∼𝒟[|p⁢(𝐱)|≤B, for all ⁢p∈𝒫β⁢(S)]≥1−ϵsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝒟𝑝𝐱𝐵 for all 𝑝subscript𝒫𝛽𝑆1italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|\leq B\,% ,\text{ for all }p\in\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)]\geq 1-\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ≤ italic_B , for all italic_p ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) ] ≥ 1 - italic_ϵ
Proof of Lemma A.2.

We first apply Lemma A.1 to show that, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over S𝑆Sitalic_S, for any p∈𝒫β⁢(S)𝑝subscript𝒫𝛽𝑆p\in\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)italic_p ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) we have 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤2⁢𝔼𝐱∼S[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤2⁢βsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑝𝐱22subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆superscript𝑝𝐱22𝛽\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq 2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 2\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 2 italic_β.

Consider now the moment matrix 𝐌=𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[ψℓ⁢(𝐱)⁢ψℓ⁢(𝐱)⊤]𝐌subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟subscript𝜓ℓ𝐱subscript𝜓ℓsuperscript𝐱top\mathbf{M}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[\psi_{\ell}(% \mathbf{x})\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})^{\top}]bold_M = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], where ψℓ⁢(𝐱)subscript𝜓ℓ𝐱\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) is the vector whose coordinates correspond to monomials of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. Let 𝐌=𝐔𝐃𝐔⊤𝐌superscript𝐔𝐃𝐔top\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{U}^{\top}bold_M = bold_UDU start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the concise SVD of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M, i.e., 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}bold_D is diagonal with dimension equal to the rank of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M, 𝐔⊤⁢𝐔=𝐈superscript𝐔top𝐔𝐈\mathbf{U}^{\top}\mathbf{U}=\mathbf{I}bold_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_U = bold_I and 𝐔𝐔⊤superscript𝐔𝐔top\mathbf{U}\mathbf{U}^{\top}bold_UU start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the orthogonal projection on the column (or row) space of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M. Let φ⁢(𝐱)=𝐃−1/2⁢𝐔⊤⁢ψℓ⁢(𝐱)𝜑𝐱superscript𝐃12superscript𝐔topsubscript𝜓ℓ𝐱\varphi(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{D}^{-1/2}\mathbf{U}^{\top}\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})italic_φ ( bold_x ) = bold_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) and observe that 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[φ⁢(𝐱)⁢φ⁢(𝐱)⊤]=𝐈subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟𝜑𝐱𝜑superscript𝐱top𝐈\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[\varphi(\mathbf{x})% \varphi(\mathbf{x})^{\top}]=\mathbf{I}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_φ ( bold_x ) italic_φ ( bold_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = bold_I and the dimension of φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ is equal to the rank of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M, which is at most (d+1)ℓsuperscript𝑑1ℓ(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here, we use the fact that all the entries of 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M are finite, due to hypercontractivity.

We may express any polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p in 𝒫β⁢(S)subscript𝒫𝛽𝑆\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) as a linear combination of the elements of φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ, i.e., p⁢(𝐱)=𝐜~p⊤⁢φ⁢(𝐱)𝑝𝐱superscriptsubscript~𝐜𝑝top𝜑𝐱p(\mathbf{x})=\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}^{\top}\varphi(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ) = over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_φ ( bold_x ), where ‖𝐜~p‖22=𝔼𝐱∼𝒟[(p⁢(𝐱))2]≤2⁢βsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐜𝑝22subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝒟superscript𝑝𝐱22𝛽\|\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}\|_{2}^{2}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim% \mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 2\beta∥ over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 2 italic_β. Moreover, we have the following due to Markov’s inequality and the fact that 𝔼[‖φ⁢(𝐱)‖22]≤(d+1)ℓ𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜑𝐱22superscript𝑑1ℓ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}]\leq(d+1)^{\ell}blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_φ ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

ℙ𝐱∼𝒟[∥φ(𝐱)∥22>B22⁢β]≤2⁢β⁢(d+1)ℓB2≤ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}\Bigr{[}\|\varphi(% \mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}>\frac{B^{2}}{2\beta}\Bigr{]}\leq\frac{2\beta(d+1)^{\ell}% }{B^{2}}\leq\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∥ italic_φ ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_β end_ARG ] ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_β ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ italic_ϵ

In the event that ‖φ⁢(𝐱)‖22≤B22⁢βsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝜑𝐱22superscript𝐵22𝛽\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{B^{2}}{2\beta}∥ italic_φ ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_β end_ARG, we have |p⁢(𝐱)|≤‖𝐜~p‖2⁢‖φ⁢(𝐱)‖2≤2⁢β⋅B2⁢β=B𝑝𝐱subscriptnormsubscript~𝐜𝑝2subscriptnorm𝜑𝐱2⋅2𝛽𝐵2𝛽𝐵|p(\mathbf{x})|\leq\|\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}\|_{2}\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}% \leq\sqrt{2\beta}\cdot\frac{B}{\sqrt{2\beta}}=B| italic_p ( bold_x ) | ≤ ∥ over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_φ ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG 2 italic_β end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_B end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_β end_ARG end_ARG = italic_B. ∎

We will also use the following theorem which is implicit in [68] and shows that polynomial approximation is sufficient to find a simple hypothesis with near-optimum error on a given dataset.

Theorem A.3 (ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression [68]).

Let S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG be a set of labeled examples and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class such that for each f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C there is some polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ such that 𝔼𝐱∼S[|f⁢(𝐱)−p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑆𝑓𝐱𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|f(\mathbf{x})-p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_ϵ. Then, the degree-ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression algorithm of [68] outputs, in time poly⁡(|S¯|⁢dℓ/ϵ)poly¯𝑆superscript𝑑ℓitalic-ϵ\operatorname{poly}(\lvert\bar{S}\rvert d^{\ell}/\epsilon)roman_poly ( | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG | italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ ), a degree-ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ polynomial threshold function hℎhitalic_h such that ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯[y≠h⁢(𝐱)]≤minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]+ϵsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝑆𝑦ℎ𝐱subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝑆𝑦𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]% \leq\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S% }}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_h ( bold_x ) ] ≤ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] + italic_ϵ.

We also give the definition of ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximating polynomials, which are sufficient for agnostic learning, but it is not clear whether they suffice for BC-learning. We instead use the notion of ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximating polynomials (Definition 4.1).

Definition A.4 (ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Polynomial Approximators).

For ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_ϵ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class 𝒞⊆{𝒳→{±1}}𝒞→𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C ⊆ { caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } } has ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree ℓ=ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓℓitalic-ϵ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ = roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) with respect to some distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C there is a polynomial p𝑝pitalic_p of degree at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) such that 𝔼𝐱∼𝒟∗[|f⁢(𝐱)−p⁢(𝐱)|]≤ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟𝑓𝐱𝑝𝐱italic-ϵ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|f(\mathbf{x})-p(% \mathbf{x})|]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ≤ italic_ϵ.

The difference between ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators is that the former enjoy the approximation property with respect to the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, while the latter with respect to the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm. Achieving ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is, in general, a stronger assumption, because the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm is upper bounded by the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, but not vice versa. Nevertheless, for most interesting classes that ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators are known, we also have ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators. This is because of analytic advantages of the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm.

Appendix B Error Lower Bounds for HC-Learning

In order to prove our lower bounds, we provide a definition for the adversary in the context of heavy contamination.

Definition B.1 (Contamination Strategy).

An algorithm ℳℳ\cal Mcaligraphic_M is called a (randomized) Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-HC strategy if, upon receiving a labeled set S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it outputs a set S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size |S¯inp|≤Q⁢|S¯cln|subscript¯𝑆inp𝑄subscript¯𝑆cln|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|\leq Q|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|| over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_Q | over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | such that S¯inp⊆S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆inpsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\subseteq\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N}italic_m ∈ blackboard_N and a labeled distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, we denote with ℳ⁢(𝒟¯m)ℳsuperscript¯𝒟𝑚{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) the distribution of the output S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ℳℳ\cal Mcaligraphic_M on a set of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. samples S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Note that S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the random choice of S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as well as the randomness of ℳℳ\cal Mcaligraphic_M.

We first prove the following lower bound, which holds for any non-trivial concept class.

Proposition B.2.

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be any concept class such that there is some f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C for which −f∈𝒞𝑓𝒞-f\in\mathcal{C}- italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C. For any Q∈{2,3,…}𝑄23…Q\in\{2,3,\dots\}italic_Q ∈ { 2 , 3 , … }, any unlabeled distribution 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, any ρ∈[0,1/2)𝜌012\rho\in[0,1/2)italic_ρ ∈ [ 0 , 1 / 2 ), ϵ,δ>0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta>0italic_ϵ , italic_δ > 0, and any m≥log⁡(2/δ)2⁢ϵ2𝑚2𝛿2superscriptitalic-ϵ2m\geq\frac{\log(2/\delta)}{2\epsilon^{2}}italic_m ≥ divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, there is a Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-HC strategy ℳℳ\cal Mcaligraphic_M and a distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG whose marginal is 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that, if we let 𝒟¯′superscript¯𝒟′\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the distribution of (𝐱,−y)𝐱𝑦(\mathbf{x},-y)( bold_x , - italic_y ), where (𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯similar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, then the following hold.

  1. 1.

    ℳ⁢(𝒟¯m)=ℳ⁢((𝒟¯′)m)ℳsuperscript¯𝒟𝑚ℳsuperscriptsuperscript¯𝒟′𝑚{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})={\cal M}((\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime})^{m})caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_M ( ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯′[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]=ρsubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦superscript¯𝒟′𝑦𝑓𝐱𝜌\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{% \mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{% \mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})% ]=\rhoroman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = italic_ρ.

  3. 3.

    With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ over S¯inp∼ℳ⁢(𝒟¯m)similar-tosubscript¯𝑆inpℳsuperscript¯𝒟𝑚\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\sim{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we have Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total≤1−ρ+ϵ⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total1𝜌italic-ϵQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}\leq 1-\rho+\epsilonitalic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 1 - italic_ρ + italic_ϵ, where 𝗈𝗉𝗍total=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼S¯inp[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp𝑦𝑓𝐱\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ].

Hence, no HC-learner for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to 𝒟∗superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can achieve error less than 12⁢(Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+𝗈𝗉𝗍clean−ϵ)12⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleanitalic-ϵ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}-\epsilon)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϵ ) with probability more than 12−δ12𝛿\frac{1}{2}-\deltadivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_δ, even when 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean=ρsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍clean𝜌\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=\rhosansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ.

Proof of Proposition B.2.

Let 𝒟=𝒟∗𝒟superscript𝒟\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Consider the following two labeled distributions. First, 𝒟¯1subscript¯𝒟1\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a distribution over 𝒳×{±1}𝒳plus-or-minus1\mathcal{X}\times\{\pm 1\}caligraphic_X × { ± 1 } whose marginal on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and the labels are generated as follows:

y1={f⁢(𝐱), with probability ⁢1−ρ−f⁢(𝐱), with probability ⁢ρsubscript𝑦1cases𝑓𝐱 with probability 1𝜌otherwise𝑓𝐱 with probability 𝜌otherwisey_{1}=\begin{cases}f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }1-\rho\\ -f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }\rho\end{cases}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability 1 - italic_ρ end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability italic_ρ end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

Consider also a distribution 𝒟¯2subscript¯𝒟2\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT whose marginal is also 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D but the labels are generated as follows:

y2={−f⁢(𝐱), with probability ⁢1−ρf⁢(𝐱), with probability ⁢ρsubscript𝑦2cases𝑓𝐱 with probability 1𝜌otherwise𝑓𝐱 with probability 𝜌otherwisey_{2}=\begin{cases}-f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }1-\rho\\ f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }\rho\end{cases}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL - italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability 1 - italic_ρ end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability italic_ρ end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

The adversary receives a set S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of m𝑚mitalic_m i.i.d. samples from 𝒟¯∈{𝒟¯1,𝒟¯2}¯𝒟subscript¯𝒟1subscript¯𝒟2\bar{\mathcal{D}}\in\{\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1},\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}\}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ∈ { over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the adversary computes the value m1=∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯inp𝟙⁡{y=f⁢(𝐱)}subscript𝑚1subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp1𝑦𝑓𝐱m_{1}=\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}% \{y=f(\mathbf{x})\}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y = italic_f ( bold_x ) }, as well as the value m2=∑(𝐱,y)∈S¯inp𝟙⁡{y=−f⁢(𝐱)}subscript𝑚2subscript𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝑆inp1𝑦𝑓𝐱m_{2}=\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}% \{y=-f(\mathbf{x})\}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y = - italic_f ( bold_x ) }.

  2. 2.

    If m1≥m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1}\geq m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the adversary adds M−m𝑀𝑚M-mitalic_M - italic_m examples drawn by 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by −f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ).

  3. 3.

    If m1<m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1}<m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the adversary adds m2−m1subscript𝑚2subscript𝑚1m_{2}-m_{1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT examples drawn by 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x})italic_f ( bold_x ), as well as M−2⁢m2𝑀2subscript𝑚2M-2m_{2}italic_M - 2 italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT examples drawn by 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by −f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ).

Part 1.

Let ξ=mi𝜉subscript𝑚𝑖\xi=m_{i}italic_ξ = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\in\{1,2\}italic_i ∈ { 1 , 2 } such that 𝒟¯=𝒟¯i¯𝒟subscript¯𝒟𝑖\bar{\mathcal{D}}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{i}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have that ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ follows the binomial distribution with parameters (m,1−ρ)𝑚1𝜌(m,1-\rho)( italic_m , 1 - italic_ρ ), and is independent from the value of i𝑖iitalic_i.

Given any realization misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ with mi>m/2subscript𝑚𝑖𝑚2m_{i}>m/2italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_m / 2, we can equivalently form the input examples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by drawing M𝑀Mitalic_M i.i.d. samples from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeling ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ of them according to f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x})italic_f ( bold_x ) and M−ξ𝑀𝜉M-\xiitalic_M - italic_ξ of them according to −f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ). We have that ℳ⁢(𝒟¯1m)|ξ>m/2=ℳ⁢(𝒟¯2m)|ξ>m/2evaluated-atℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟1𝑚𝜉𝑚2evaluated-atℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟2𝑚𝜉𝑚2{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m})|_{\xi>m/2}={\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}^% {m})|_{\xi>m/2}caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ > italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ > italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Given any realization misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ with mi≤m/2subscript𝑚𝑖𝑚2m_{i}\leq m/2italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_m / 2, we can equivalently form the input examples S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by drawing M𝑀Mitalic_M i.i.d. samples from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeling m−ξ𝑚𝜉m-\xiitalic_m - italic_ξ of them according to f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x})italic_f ( bold_x ) and M−m+ξ𝑀𝑚𝜉M-m+\xiitalic_M - italic_m + italic_ξ of them according to −f⁢(𝐱)𝑓𝐱-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ). We, therefore, have ℳ⁢(𝒟¯1m)|ξ≤m/2=ℳ⁢(𝒟¯2m)|ξ≤m/2evaluated-atℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟1𝑚𝜉𝑚2evaluated-atℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟2𝑚𝜉𝑚2{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m})|_{\xi\leq m/2}={\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_% {2}^{m})|_{\xi\leq m/2}caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ≤ italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ≤ italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Overall, since ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ does not depend on i𝑖iitalic_i, we have ℳ⁢(𝒟¯1m)=ℳ⁢(𝒟¯2m)ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟1𝑚ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟2𝑚{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m})={\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}^{m})caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Part 2.

Follows immediately from the fact that f,−f∈𝒞𝑓𝑓𝒞f,-f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f , - italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C and the definition of 𝒟¯=𝒟¯1¯𝒟subscript¯𝒟1\bar{\mathcal{D}}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒟¯′=𝒟¯2superscript¯𝒟′subscript¯𝒟2\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Part 3.

Regarding the error benchmark, we have Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total=max⁡{ξ,m−ξ}m≤1−ρ+ϵ⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total𝜉𝑚𝜉𝑚1𝜌italic-ϵQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=\frac{\max\{\xi,m-\xi\}}{m}\leq 1-\rho+\epsilonitalic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG roman_max { italic_ξ , italic_m - italic_ξ } end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ≤ 1 - italic_ρ + italic_ϵ, whenever |ξ−(1−ρ)⁢m|≤ϵ⁢m𝜉1𝜌𝑚italic-ϵ𝑚|\xi-(1-\rho)m|\leq\epsilon m| italic_ξ - ( 1 - italic_ρ ) italic_m | ≤ italic_ϵ italic_m, which happens with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, according to the following inequality.

ℙ[|ξ−(1−ρ)⁢m|>ϵ⁢m]≤2⁢exp⁡(−2⁢ϵ2⁢m)≤δℙ𝜉1𝜌𝑚italic-ϵ𝑚22superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑚𝛿\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}[|\xi-(1-\rho)m|>\epsilon m]\leq 2\exp(% -2\epsilon^{2}m)\leq\deltablackboard_P [ | italic_ξ - ( 1 - italic_ρ ) italic_m | > italic_ϵ italic_m ] ≤ 2 roman_exp ( - 2 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m ) ≤ italic_δ

The bound follows from an application of Hoeffding’s inequality, since ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is binomial of mean (1−ρ)⁢m1𝜌𝑚(1-\rho)m( 1 - italic_ρ ) italic_m. It follows that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, the algorithm outputs a hypothesis with error at least 12⁢(Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+𝗈𝗉𝗍clean−ϵ)12⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleanitalic-ϵ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}-\epsilon)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϵ ).

Implication to HC Learning.

We have ℳ⁢(𝒟¯1m)=ℳ⁢(𝒟¯2m)ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟1𝑚ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟2𝑚{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m})={\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}^{m})caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A be any, potentially randomized algorithm, and let h:=𝒜⁢(ℳ⁢(𝒟¯1m))=𝒜⁢(ℳ⁢(𝒟¯2m))assignℎ𝒜ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟1𝑚𝒜ℳsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒟2𝑚h:=\mathcal{A}({\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m}))=\mathcal{A}({\cal M}(\bar{% \mathcal{D}}_{2}^{m}))italic_h := caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_M ( over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) be the random variable corresponding to its output, where h:𝒳→{±1}:ℎ→𝒳plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 }. Consider the event that hℎhitalic_h is such that: ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯1[h⁢(𝐱)≠y]<1/2subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝒟1ℎ𝐱𝑦12\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}}[h(\mathbf% {x})\neq y]<1/2blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) ≠ italic_y ] < 1 / 2. Then, we have:

ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯2[h⁢(𝐱)≠−y]subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝒟2ℎ𝐱𝑦\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{% 2}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq-y]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) ≠ - italic_y ] =ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯1[h⁢(𝐱)≠−y]=1−ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯1[h⁢(𝐱)≠y]>1/2absentsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝒟1ℎ𝐱𝑦1subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦subscript¯𝒟1ℎ𝐱𝑦12\displaystyle=\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_% {1}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq-y]=1-\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar% {\mathcal{D}}_{1}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq y]>1/2= blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) ≠ - italic_y ] = 1 - blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) ≠ italic_y ] > 1 / 2

Note that the same is true even if hℎhitalic_h is a randomized classifier. Overall, the error of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on either 𝒟¯1subscript¯𝒟1\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or 𝒟¯2subscript¯𝒟2\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 1/2121/21 / 2 with probability at least 1/2121/21 / 2. Finally, due to part 3, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, we have 1/2≥12⁢(Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total+𝗈𝗉𝗍clean−ϵ)1212⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍totalsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleanitalic-ϵ1/2\geq\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{% clean}}-\epsilon)1 / 2 ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϵ ), which implies the desired result. ∎

For finite feature spaces and the particular choice of the class of all functions, we obtain a sharper information-theoretic lower bound on the error. Note that this lower bound captures the problem of HC-learning halfspaces over {±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ ± 1 } in one dimension.

Proposition B.3.

Suppose that |𝒳|<∞𝒳|\mathcal{X}|<\infty| caligraphic_X | < ∞ and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is any concept class from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X to {±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ ± 1 }. Then, on any value of Q𝑄Qitalic_Q in {2,3,…}23…\{2,3,\dots\}{ 2 , 3 , … }, any (distribution-specific) HC-learner will output a hypothesis with error 1111 with probability at least 2−|𝒳|superscript2𝒳2^{-|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on some instance where Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total=1⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total1Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Moreover, if 𝒞={±1}𝒳𝒞superscriptplus-or-minus1𝒳\mathcal{C}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C = { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the instance satisfies 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean=0subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Proof of Proposition B.3.

The adversary receives the clean dataset S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and creates a duplicate S¯cln′superscriptsubscript¯𝑆cln′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where all the labels are flipped but the feature vectors are unchanged. Then, the adversary draws (Q−2)⋅m⋅𝑄2𝑚(Q-2)\cdot m( italic_Q - 2 ) ⋅ italic_m i.i.d. examples S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the marginal distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X of the clean distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG and labels them according to f1subscript𝑓1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The input dataset is S¯cln∪S¯cln′∪S¯′subscript¯𝑆clnsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑆cln′superscript¯𝑆′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note that the input dataset is completely independent from the clean labels, since S¯cln∪S¯cln′subscript¯𝑆clnsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑆cln′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be constructed equivalently by choosing an arbitrary function g:𝒳→{±1}:𝑔→𝒳plus-or-minus1g:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_g : caligraphic_X → { ± 1 } to label the points in S¯clnsubscript¯𝑆cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then label the points in S¯cln′superscriptsubscript¯𝑆cln′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT according to −g𝑔-g- italic_g.

Therefore, we may assume that the ground truth labels are generated by the function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where −f∗superscript𝑓-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the most likely output of the HC-learner on a dataset of the form S¯cln∪S¯cln′∪S¯′subscript¯𝑆clnsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑆cln′superscript¯𝑆′\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since there are at most 2|𝒳|superscript2𝒳2^{|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible functions, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A must output −f∗superscript𝑓-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with probability at least 2−|𝒳|superscript2𝒳2^{-|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. When 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs −f∗superscript𝑓-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the error is 1111.

Finally, note that f1subscript𝑓1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT achieves error on S¯inpsubscript¯𝑆inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to 1/Q1𝑄1/Q1 / italic_Q, so 𝗈𝗉𝗍total=1/Qsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total1𝑄\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1/Qsansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_Q and Q⋅𝗈𝗉𝗍total=1⋅𝑄subscript𝗈𝗉𝗍total1Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1italic_Q ⋅ sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

When 𝒞={±1}𝒳𝒞superscriptplus-or-minus1𝒳\mathcal{C}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C = { ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have f∗∈𝒞superscript𝑓𝒞f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_C and, hence, 𝗈𝗉𝗍clean:=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]=0assignsubscript𝗈𝗉𝗍cleansubscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}:=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}% }_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = 0. ∎

Appendix C Approximation Theory Results

C.1 Low-Degree Approximators

Our structural Theorem 4.2 can be combined with results from polynomial approximation theory in order to obtain end-to-end results on learning with nasty noise, including the results of Table 2.

Intersections of Halfspaces.

For the class of k𝑘kitalic_k-halfspace intersections, [74] showed that the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree with respect to the standard Gaussian distribution 𝒩dsubscript𝒩𝑑\mathcal{N}_{d}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Definition 4.1) is ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(log⁡(k)/ϵ2)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\log(k)/\epsilon^{2})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and [63] obtains the same result with respect to the uniform distribution UnifdsubscriptUnif𝑑\operatorname{Unif}_{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the hypercube.

Monotone Functions and Convex Sets.

For monotone functions, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree with respect to UnifdsubscriptUnif𝑑\operatorname{Unif}_{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was bounded by ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(d/ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂𝑑italic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\sqrt{d}/\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_ϵ ) in [14]. For convex sets, [74] showed that the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree with respect to the Gaussian distribution can be bounded via the Gaussian Surface Area (GSA). Combined with the result of [2] on the GSA of convex sets, the corresponding bound is ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(d/ϵ2)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\sqrt{d}/\epsilon^{2})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Polynomial Threshold Functions.

For the class of degree-k𝑘kitalic_k PTFs, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree with respect to the standard Gaussian was bounded by ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(k2/ϵ2)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂superscript𝑘2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(k^{2}/\epsilon^{2})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in [60]. In [62], it was shown that ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤kO⁢(k2)⁢(log⁡1/ϵ)O⁢(k⁢log⁡k)ϵ2ℓitalic-ϵsuperscript𝑘𝑂superscript𝑘2superscript1italic-ϵ𝑂𝑘𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq\frac{k^{O(k^{2})}(\log 1/\epsilon)^{O(k\log k)}}{\epsilon^{% 2}}roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log 1 / italic_ϵ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k roman_log italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG with respect to the uniform over {±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ ± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Low-depth Circuits.

For the class of 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits of size s𝑠sitalic_s and depth t𝑡titalic_t, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate degree is known to be at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)=O⁢(log⁡(s))t−1⁢log⁡(1/ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂superscript𝑠𝑡11italic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)=O(\log(s))^{t-1}\log(1/\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) = italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_s ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_ϵ ), due to the seminal work of [81] and subsequent improvements [88].

C.2 Sandwiching Approximators

For the more challenging problem of learning with heavy contamination, we require the existence of sandwiching approximators (see Theorem 4.4), and show that arbitrary (non-sandwiching) approximators do not suffice (see Theorem 5.2).

Decision Trees of Halfspaces.

For the class of depth-t𝑡titalic_t, size-s𝑠sitalic_s decision trees of halfspaces, [53] showed that the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-sandwiching degree with respect to either the standard Gaussian or the uniform on the hypercube is ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O~⁢(t4⁢s2ϵ2)ℓitalic-ϵ~𝑂superscript𝑡4superscript𝑠2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq\tilde{O}(\frac{t^{4}s^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ).

Low-Depth Circuits.

The ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-sandwiching degree of 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits of depth t𝑡titalic_t and size s𝑠sitalic_s is known to be at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(log⁡(s))O⁢(t)⁢log⁡(1/ϵ)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂superscript𝑠𝑂𝑡1italic-ϵ\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\log(s))^{O(t)}\log(1/\epsilon)roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_s ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_ϵ ), due to the celebrated results of [12, 88, 57].

Polynomial Threshold Functions.

The ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-sandwiching degree of degree-k𝑘kitalic_k PTFs over the Gaussian was bounded by ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤Ok⁢(ϵ−4⁢k⋅7k)ℓitalic-ϵsubscript𝑂𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ⋅4𝑘superscript7𝑘\ell(\epsilon)\leq O_{k}(\epsilon^{-4k\cdot 7^{k}})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_k ⋅ 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in [87], based on the pseudorandom generator of [61]. Here, Ok⁢(⋅)subscript𝑂𝑘⋅O_{k}(\cdot)italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is hiding a multiplicative factor that scales as an arbitrary function of k𝑘kitalic_k. For k=2𝑘2k=2italic_k = 2, the sandwiching degree with respect to the uniform distribution over the hypercube is known to be at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤O⁢(1/ϵ9)ℓitalic-ϵ𝑂1superscriptitalic-ϵ9\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(1/\epsilon^{9})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ italic_O ( 1 / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) due to [36].

Functions of Halfspaces over Log-Concave Measures.

For arbitrary functions of k𝑘kitalic_k halfspaces, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-sandwiching degree with respect to any log-concave distribution was shown to be at most ℓ⁢(ϵ)≤exp⁡((log⁡(log⁡(k)/ϵ))O⁢(k)/ϵ4)ℓitalic-ϵsuperscript𝑘italic-ϵ𝑂𝑘superscriptitalic-ϵ4\ell(\epsilon)\leq\exp((\log(\log(k)/\epsilon))^{O(k)}/\epsilon^{4})roman_ℓ ( italic_ϵ ) ≤ roman_exp ( ( roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_ϵ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by [73, 67].

Appendix D Complexity of Learning with Adversarial Label Noise

The computational complexity of agnostic learning (or equivalently learning with adversarial label noise) is much better understood than the complexity of learning with contamination. In this setting, the learner receives i.i.d. examples from some labeled distribution 𝒟¯¯𝒟\bar{\mathcal{D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG whose marginal on the feature space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is well-behaved (i.e., Gaussian or uniform) and is, otherwise, arbitrary. The goal is to output, with high probability, a hypothesis whose error is at most 𝗈𝗉𝗍+ϵ𝗈𝗉𝗍italic-ϵ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_ϵ, where 𝗈𝗉𝗍=minf∈𝒞⁢ℙ(𝐱,y)∼𝒟¯[y≠f⁢(𝐱)]𝗈𝗉𝗍subscript𝑓𝒞subscriptℙsimilar-to𝐱𝑦¯𝒟𝑦𝑓𝐱\mathsf{opt}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)% \sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) ∼ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y ≠ italic_f ( bold_x ) ], for some target concept class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C.

Upper Bounds.

On the upper bound side, [68] showed that any class with bounded ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree admits dimension-efficient agnostic learners via low-degree ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression. Several prior and subsequent works provided such bounds for many fundamental classes, based on Fourier or Hermite analysis [81, 14, 25, 60, 62, 63], as well as geometric properties of Gaussian spaces [74]. Note that the usual way to bound the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree, is to first bound the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree and then use Cauchy-Schwarz inequality. This is because bounding the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is usually more analytically convenient. However, this approach does not always give tight results for the degree in terms of the approximation error. In [46], it was shown that ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation bounds over the hypercube can be obtained directly for any function class with bounded noise sensitivity.

Lower Bounds.

The complexity of agnostic learning with respect to Gaussian marginals was shown to be characterized in terms of the ℒ1subscriptℒ1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree for algorithms that fall in the statistical query (SQ) framework by [37], implying the lower bounds of Table 4 for intersections of halfspaces and polynomial threshold functions. For the uniform distribution on the hypercube, a similar characterization was given by [42]. Moreover, [4] showed an information-theoretic lower bound for learning monotone functions even in the realizable setting, implying the lower bound of Table 4 for monotone functions. For 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits, [65] provided a cryptographic lower bound.
